item.title: Real Wedding//Jill & Jeremy
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
These two lovebirds. REALLLLLY!? -fabulous. They are. They were married a little while back, but I realized that their beautiful shining faces hadn't made it to our new blog. Jill and Jeremy were married at the Aspen Wye River Conference Center. It was the perfect backdrop for their outdoor garden wedding. I was reading through the amazing Megan Beth Photography's blog and she told such a sweet story of their wedding day. For their first dance, they met on the dance floor and the music started. Seconds later as Jeremy spun Jill around the floor she looked up and realized, it wasn't the dj. It was Jeremy's sister and her husband serenading them. Such a beautiful moment. Jill and Jeremy had a beautiful day, surrounded by a strong supportive group of friends and family. Jill, thank you for letting us come in to help make you and your ladies beautiful. Xo, Alison

item.title: Personal//Picture Perfect
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
A week ago, I was sitting at my desk. Alone in the office, everyone had left. I rarely answer the phone myself these days and it wasdefinitelyafter hours. I was writing out my to do list for the next day when one of the phones lit up. Without a thought I picked it up. It was a bride. She was asking about availability, pricing and trial runs. We chatted for a bit and I set up a consult for her and she asked "What do I have to do to have you hold my date?" I cautioned her to do a little comparison shopping, look around a little bit. I don't want my clients to run head first into our services. I want to make sure that we are what they really want. No pressure. In a very serious tone shereplied"No, I know what I need. You guys are it." Sheproceededto tell me a quick story that I've heard a hundred times over. Each time I hear it, a little part of my heart cracks.
Photo byDani Leigh Photography
She had a friend who had gotten married last year. She found her makeup artist on craigslist.[Now, I caution here. I am sure there are plenty of talented people who advertise on craigslist. However they are grossly outnumbered by the amateur artists on craigslist]She found her makeup artist on craigslist for an affordable application. The morning of the wedding the artist showed up, did the makeup and went on her merry way. The bride cried about her makeup and before she walked down the aisle her bridesmaids scrambled to fix it. She told me that her friend wont even hang the photos from her wedding in their house. She is too upset about how she looked. The makeup looked nothing like her, a little too tan, she never wears eyeliner and you can see the difference from her face to her neck in color. You get the idea. I know that this sounds dramatic. Really, I appreciate that it does. Think about it. You are spending a lot of money on a beautiful venue, amazing photography. You've searched online for days and visited the dress shop multiple times for that perfect, very expensive dress.Why would someone want to pay for a half rate makeup application. This is how you look. This is personal. You are the bride, you are in every photo. If you don't like how you look, it is going to dramatically effect how you feel about your wedding photos.That is a fact.
The beautiful Meredith onher wedding day. Photo byBrian Tropiano Photography
I'm not sure why I am telling this story. If you are reading this blog, it is in hopes that you respect what we do and see the value in it. I think I am writing this because it upsets me every time I hear it. I am in the business of making someone look and feel beautiful.Confident. Radiant. That is my job andI take it very seriously.It really makes me feel for each individual that this happens to. I guess I am telling you this to help spread the word. If you know someone who is getting married, encourage them to go the professional route. It doesn't have to be with us. I would prefer a bride to go with our competition and be happy rather than go with a cheaper alternative and hate their photos. We aren't for everyone, but everyone that we are for, is well taken care of. We want you to feel beautiful. Confident & radiant. We want you to love your photos. The feelings you get when you look at them should have nothing to do with your makeup or hair. Your feelings should be exclusively about the memories from your wedding day. The excitement, the nervousness, the tears, the beauty, the kiss. Your love, not about your makeup. Go with a professional. xo. Alison
Our beautiful bride Katie & her dad before the ceremony. Photo by my favoriteChristine Barker Photography

item.title: Alison Harper Style//Oh My
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
I was at a bridal show a few months back. Chatting with brides, answering questions and doing demos. A bride approached my table and asked about pricing. I answered and she huffed back "oh, yeah right. I'll just go to a makeup counter at least I get to keep the product." OH MY. WHAT?! Be still my beating heart. I held mytonguebut I realized that she could not be the only bride considering this option. I decided to give this a try. See why someone would consider this as an option for their wedding. My friend Christine fromChristine Barker Photographythought this would be an amazingopportunityto showcase the power of quality makeup in photographs.We decided to see what would happen when a bride uses this avenue to get her makeup done and then to see how well it photographs. To start this experiment, I called to set up an appointment at the MAC counter. They answered and told me that they don't make them. I could drop in and get it done that day. Perfect. Christine and I arrived when the store opened at 10a to get our makeup done. We were the only clients and we we're greeted by 5 makeup artists. We asked if we could get our makeup done for my wedding. I told them I needed to be back at the hotel for my ceremony at 2p.[ah, lies. I know.]The artist flipped through her book and told us they were all booked up.We were told to come back at 1p, they didn't have anyone to do it until then. Yeah, on my so called wedding day, I was blown off by 5 makeup artists. I was told that they don't take appointments, and apparently they do. Well I mean the other artists we're busy.. you know chatting with each other and drinking their starbucks.. Christine and I stepped outside to regroup. Well, that sure foiled our plan. We decided to try another makeup counter, just as any bride would have to do on her wedding day in this situation. We went into the bareessentialsstore. For a few dollars in product you can get your makeup done. Perfect! I assume that this is what a bride would do if MAC turned them away, right? Our artists were friendly and sanitary.. and trying to sell us product. I asked for a soft, simple and natural application. Although I did leave with a really pretty set of eye shadows and a mascara, our application took 3 hours. By the time we were finished, "my wedding" should have already started. I am not telling you this to sound like I am bashing anyone. The artists that did our makeup were really pleasant, the products I left with were nice and Christine and I had a good time. This is the perfect idea for a Saturday afternoon if you are looking for something fun to do with your girls. However. This is a really terrible idea for your wedding day. Besides the obvious reasons, I will let the images below speak for themselves. Christine and I returned to her studio and photographed my makeup with her professional equipment. I had one of our artists come and do professional airbrush on me as well. We photographed the makeup by an Alison Harper & Company artist under the same exact settings. These photos are not retouched. They are photographed under the same lights, same settings and with the same camera.See for yourself. I hope that this post will save at least one client from the hassle and heartache. Go with a professional when its so important. Save the counter for a fun afternoon with your girls, not your wedding day. xo, Alison

item.title: Personal//Silent Questions
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: When we had talked about marriage, you used to get this look in your eyes. Your bright blue eyes would go a shade darker and the set of your mouth would be a little tighter. You never really said it, but your face gave you away. You were wondering if I really understood what forever was. If I was really ready to make that commitment. Since you never asked, I never answered. I had the answer. I knew it the moment I saw you. I knew it the moment you dropped onto your knee. I knew it when you asked. I made you wait and I stared into your eyes and I saw that color shift. I knew. I silently answered the silent question that you didn't ask. Yes, I meant forever. We are going to fight, we are going to argue. This is life. It isn't going to be easy. We're going to have rough days, -hell, rough years. That doesn't matter. There are going to be speed bumps, tragedies and 7 year itches. That is going to happen. I'm going to go through all of this with you. If you think I'm going to let these things push through us, you are wrong. You and I will make it through this life together. So yes, you will bethe hand I clutch when we welcome our future children into the world. You will be my Tuesdaylasagnanight dinner date, my sounding board. My support, my confidante. My cheerleader, myguardian, my advocate. You and I will do this forever. I will be yours and you will be mine. No one will ever have the part of my heart that you have. Xo, Alison

item.title: Real Wedding//Cristal & Orialys
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Today, I want you to meet two very beautiful women. They came up to DC from Miami to get married. You see, when they got married [what feels like a million years ago] Same sex marriage was legal in only a few locations. DC being one of them. They flew up here, brought their family and celebrated an amazing union between two very caring individuals. I remember meetingCristal and Orialys at a starbucks across from their hotel to go over everything with them. If anyone ever doubted that they were meant for each other you could see it. Within minutes we were chatting and they were finishing each others sentences. I was so excited for us to be a part of their wedding day. They deserved to honor their love and to publicly proclaim that they will love and support each other.. and they did. [They looked darn good doing it too.] Cristal & Orialys, it was great working with you. You two were such joys and your wedding day looks like a fairy tale. Thank you for allowing us to be a part of your day. Thank you also, for allowing us to share your wedding and your love with everyone. You two rock.
Xo, Alison
These photos are thanks toShelly Guberek. Special shout out toBlue Canary Events! The talented event planning company that made this day amazing.

item.title: Alison Harper Style//Chic Wedding Inspiration
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
When I was planning my own wedding I scoured the web and checked in on some of my favorite local blogs. I love local blogs; United with Love, Charm City Wed, District Weddings, Capital Romance, Bayside Bride. Sometimes though, it is nice to see a little more variety and to gain a little more inspiration from across the wedding globe. After a following a few local blogs, I grew tired of mason jars and similar photographers. I wanted a little variety. Below are a few of my favorite inspirational wedding blogs. I hope this adds a little spice to your regular blog routine.

Alison

//Vogue Weddings//
We all know Vogue. Its classic, its fashion -its so chic.. and I rarely use that word. Their new wedding guide holds up to that same standard. Their weddings are timeless, elegant and very detail oriented. They feature celebrity weddings, real weddings and they are all organized by theme. Scoot on over there to see some of the prettiest flowers I have ever laid my eyes on.

Photo Credit:Vogue Wedding Guide

//Wed Luxe//
With the tag line "True Love, True Luxury", this blog is the foremost in luxury weddings. They post about all things wedding , from speakeasy wedding inspiration to packing for your honey moon. I love WedLuxe. They started as a beautiful, large scale Canadian wedding magazine and expanded into the bridal market. Almost 300 pages of the some of the best real wedding spreads.

Photo Credit:Wed Luxe

//Grace Ormonde Weddings//
You've seen the magazine. If you haven't you need to. Its beautiful, heavy and they feature some of the most over the top, beautiful weddings. I also love that they interview some of industry's leading vendors for honest, frank and well needed feedback. If you are looking for something that gives a little more than your regular blog routine scoot your pretty butt over there.

Photo Credit:Grace Ormonde Weddings

item.title: Alison Harper Style//The Perfect Red
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Finding the perfect, illusive red is a pivotal day in a woman's life. Nothing can change your outlook like a pair of high heels and the perfect red lip. For most of us, its very difficult to find.
Photo Credit: Marcella Treybig Photography Makeup: Gabriela
Step 1//Wash your face Remove all eye makeup, blush and liner. You'll need a completely fresh face to decide on the correct color. Step 2// Decide your undertone There are three types of undertones: Cool(pink, red or bluish undertones) Warm(yellow or golden undertones) Neutral(a mix of warm and cool undertones) It may seem complicated to determine but it is actually quite simple. Study your clean face in a mirror. It is preferable to do this in natural light, so that your skin isn't tinted by artificial light. One test to help determine your undertone is to do the towel test. Pull your hair back and away from your face. Take a white towel or cloth and drape the cloth around your shoulders, neck and head. In comparison to the towel your skin will reflect its true undertone.If your face looks more yellow, youre warm. If your skin has a blue tone youre cool. Another basic guideline is; if you look good in silver, you probably have a cool undertone. If you look better in gold, then you're warm. If you look good in both, youre probably neutral. Step 3// Basic Rules Cool undertones, stick to a blue based red lipstick Warm undertones, stick to a red lipstick with aslight brown or orange component You should also pay attention to your skin shade as well as the undertone: Lighter: Corals or hints of orange Medium: slight brown or orange component Bronze: Cranberry or pink based colors Dark: Fig or cool based reds
Warm Undertones:
Bobbi Brown Burnt Red;MAC Lustre Capricious;Laura Mercier Italian Summer
Cool Undertones
NARS Heat Wave; Dolce & Gabbana Ruby; Shiseido Valentine
Photo Credit: Adam Barnes Fine Art Photography

Okay, enough gushing. Congrats Kelly, you looked fantastic. xo, Alison
Many thanks to the amazing photographer: Deb Lindsey Photography

item.title: Personal//69 Years Ago
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
69 years agomy grandmotherwoke up and buttoned her brown checkered dress, slipped into her brownsuedesling backs and wrapped her mink around her shoulders. She was headed to the alter to marry her love. Most women of her era lived for their wedding. Marriage was what they were raised for in the 30s and 40s. You were raised proper and then you married and made a home. A wedding was a womans coming of age, you had announcements in the paper, beautiful gifts and dresses. It was a very big ta-do in a womans life. You have to understand the sacrifice that my grandmother made when she married my grandfather in 1944. She didn't get to wear white, she didn't get to walk down the aisle and she didn't get to meet her groom at the altar. You see, my grandmother was Catholic. My grandfather, well he wasn't practicing anything. It was a pretty big scandal at the time. The church wouldn't allow my grandparents the right to a full catholic wedding with out two fullCatholics. My grandmother wore brown, she married my grandfather in a quiet ceremony in the churches vestry. No bells, no whistles, no wedding announcements, no big party. My grandmother sacrificed these menial details because she was marrying the man she loved.
My grandparents on their wedding day; April 8, 1944.
Five days after this beautifully, simple ceremony my grandfather, Rex was shipped off to war. My grandmother, Jean wrote him a letter every single day for the entire year he was deployed. Every single day. He was living in a boat, traveling Europe and fighting for our country. He never received a single letter. It turns out that while he was away, his mail had never been forwarded. When he finally landed state side in New York, there was an entire trunk full of his brand new wife's love.
____________________________________________
My Grandmother Jean on her wedding day.
My grandparents had a beautiful marriage.In the 40's and 50's men had their role and women had another. Their marriage was different. They were a team, they were fighting battles together and were on the same side.My grandfather loved my grandmother. He truly, truly cherished her. He would help around the house leaving her little notes. He doted on my grandmother. On the other hand, my grandmother was a rock in their household. She was a loyal, polished and supportive wife. They raised 9 successful and brilliant children, traveled the world and deeply loved each other. My grandfather battled with different forms of cancer anddementialater in his life. My grandmother stood by his side during his 10 year fight.It was a long, long road.She insisted on keeping him at home, not in a nursing home. She cared for him all the way to the end of his life, holding his hand, feeding him and talking to him. He died only a few short years ago. My grandmother honored his memory, remained faithful and remained his until she lost her life to bone cancer this past year.
My grandfathers militaryhead shotcirca 1942-1945ish.
My grandparents and the dedication they had to their marriage has left me with this rose colored view on love. They have given all of my cousins and I a fine example of how much work it takes to have such a solid andflourishingmarriage. I can only hope that my husband and I will have half of the marriage that my grandparents had. Both of my grandparents are celebrating their first anniversary together in quite a few years. I miss them terribly but I know that they have a legacy and I am proud to be a part of that. Today, I want to acknowledge a love and a marriage that was strong, caring and truly beautiful. xo, Alison

item.title: Real Wedding//Alisa & Kevin
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:

item.title: Personal//Clean, Crisp, Masculine
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
I want morning and noon and nightfall with you. I want your tears, your smiles, your kisses.. the smell of your hair, the taste of your skin, the touch of your breath on my face. I want to see you in the final hours of my life.. to lie in your arms as I take my last breath. Hussein Nishah
Photo Credit:Michelle Lindsey Photography
In college I worked at the DeafIndependentLiving Association and I went for my undergrad in Deaf Studies. Living so in depth in the deaf community you learn to stop listening. You rely on your other senses to compensate for your needs. Besides relying on feel and sight, I learned the power of smell. A scent can bring a memory rushing back through your brain just like the sound of someones voice. We all know the scents of our childhood, of autumn, the holidays and the beach. Each ripples through your brain and can bring you back there in seconds.
____________________________________
On our fourth date Jd invited me over to watch a movie. It was a bold move, we hadn't hung out in private yet. We sat awkwardly on his couch while I sung along to the opening song for the movie Juno. Once the movie started, we relaxed a little and he put his arm around the back of the couch. I sunk in and relaxed. At some point during the movie I leaned in and rested my head on his chest. That area. You know that area, between his shoulder and chest. The one part of him that I feel was carved out for me to curl up into. I remember the end of Juno, where Juno and Paulie were curled up in the hospital bed together crying. It was such a beautiful moment in the movie. I did that thing that girls do, I cleared my throat, touched my eyes. I tried to not let him see my eyes water. Don't we all want a guy to rush in at the end and love us right when we need it? I sunk into his shoulder and breathed deep. I will never forget that moment. It was a moment that I memorized his smell. It was a masculine clean smell. Like tide, fresh and crisp. I took it all in and commited it to memory. It was such a clear representation of him. He is a simple, organized, steady man. His scent was the same; clean, simple and steady. Later that night, when I went home I curled up in my own bed. Smiling deep into my pillow I noticed my own scent. Floral and light, busy and just a bit sweet. Such a perfect example of my individualism. I toocommittedto memory that scent. I memorized the melody of my own perfume. I wanted to be able to remember this happy feeling, getting to know someone new and falling for him.
Photo Credit:Dani Leigh Photography
I didn't know then that this man would be my husband. I didn't know that we would plan and build a life together. When I was curled up on the couch with him on that fourth date, I didn't know that he would be the paulie to my juno. A few weeks ago, I traveled away on business. I was gone for almost an entire 2 weeks. When I finally came home I curled up on the couch with my cuddly schnauzer and relaxed. It was beautiful, 70 degree day and I had the windows open with a soft breeze. It was quiet and I was so happy to finally be home. I took a deep breath and realized that we have our own scent. As a family unit we have merged and have our own unique perfume. It was clean, and floral. Bright and crisp. It was a perfect harmony of the two of us. Unique to us and completely and totally made of the two of us as individuals. I committed that to memory too. When we have hard moments and tough challenges, I want to remember that day. That afternoon when I was so happy to be in our home. I couldn't wait to see him, to touch his face. To breath him in. xo, Alison

item.title: Personal//Confessions
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
I had sushi with two friends last night and over a warm sake we shared ideas, dreams and deep thoughts and things. I shared my ideas about travel and life. It was beautiful to be heard and to share. I think I feel more connected to someone that I've confessed things too. I think we should make it a habit to share who we are. So I confess:
//I'm not really a blond// I wish I had better handwriting// My favorite thing to do on a Saturday night includes Tabitha's Salon Takeover and a Chipotle bowl// I was once asked to leave a step workout class because I am not coordinated enough// I dvr old episodes of the golden girls// my mom is one of my best friends// I suffer from serious road rage and a heavy foot// I cuddle with my dog more than my husband// I have an addiction to Krispy Kreme // I have never found a red lipstick that I like//

item.title: Alison Harper Style//Getting the most from your hair and make up trial
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Photo Credit:Melissa Barrick Photography Makeup by Katy
A trial, consultation or practice run is a service that your hair or makeup artist perform as a dry run for your wedding day look. In most cases this will be done by the actual artist who will be performing your services the day of your wedding. With our team, our trials are performed at your location with the actual artists that are scheduled for your wedding day. We always suggest scheduling around 3 hours for your trial so that you can get the most out of your experience. We want to make sure you get the opportunity to find the perfect look for you and try out different styles. Make sure to adhere to these tips for getting the most out of your trial whether it is with us or another talented artist. Here's to you finding the perfect look for your wedding day!
Evan's wedding day makeup by Jen
Wear a white shirt// Have you ever noticed how most salons have bright, natural lighting? Your skin can change shade slightly based on what is surrounding it. If you have on a red shirt, your skin will have a slight pink tinge to it, etc. This makes your makeup artist's job a bit difficult in matching your natural skin color. Also, you'll be wearing white at your wedding, it may be best to see how your skin and the over all coloring will appear next to your dress. Have clean air dried hair// It is a common misconception to have 'one day dirty' hair. It is always preferable to work with clean hair. If your scalp is too oily, it may create difficulty creating the volume you may need.Also, when you flat iron, blow dry or curl your hair you are temporarily changing the structure. Once its been changed its difficult for us to get it to do anything else. It is best for your stylist to see your hair in its natural state to best understand what foundation they may be working with. Have pictures// This is one of the most important tips. Pictures of hair and makeup ideas help your artist to understand what you are trying to explain. There are endless shades of browns, pinks and reds. Your artist will need to know what you have in mind so that they can be create what you would like to see. I also suggest to my clients to bring photos of hair and makeup that they don't like, so I know what to steer away from. Remember that it is a practice run// Although this is a dry run of your wedding day, keep in mind that this may be the first time your artist may be working with your hair or skin. On the wedding day they will already know how your skin or hair reacts to different products or techniques; yielding better results. It is quite common for our clients to have adjustments and changes to their hair or makeup after the trial. Once they have worn the look, the feedback is appreciated. A good stylist or makeup artist should be able to adapt their service based on your feedback on the wedding day. Surround yourself with honest, loving feedback// A friend or family member's feedback is quite important. I urge you though, when planning your trial run; surround yourself with people who know your normal appearance. Occasionally your makeup artist may do a specific look that is just slightly off, you like it but you can't quite pin why it doesn't look like you. A familiar friend can usually spot the adjustment. Be careful though to surround yourself with people who are coming from a loving place. You will want honest, knowledgeable and constructive feedback. Have your accessories// Although your veil, earrings or even your teeka won't dramatically change the way your hair or makeup is done; it will help you with a complete visual of your look. This will help you to make decisions about specifics of your overall appearance. Most veils have similar application, so if you don't have it with you, don't panic. Your artist, should still know how to place or apply your accessory. Bring a camera// Your trial is a complete practice of your wedding day look. Most stylists in salon are not prepared with a camera during their work day. I would urge you not to rely on your stylist to take photos or to remember each nuance of your style. If you want to have the most accurate match, take photos after your salon visit and bring them with you on your wedding day. Any bridal specialist should be prepared with techniques to remember your look. Our artists will take notes and photos of your look as a reminder, but in most cases you wouldn't want to rely on this, in the event that the stylist in your salon is not prepared.
Interested in setting up a trial with one of our talented Alison Harper & Company beauty experts? Email us today at Info@AlisonHarperAndCompany.com. "Why wouldn't you want to look your best?"
Photo Credit:Eli Turner Studios Hair & Makeup by Gabriela

item.title: Personal//Love Notes
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
I woke this morning thinking of my grandparents. I'm not sure why. Just like anyone who has lost someone your mind occasionally wanders and you are stuck with that on your mind for the day. My grandparents were supportive, loving and had a beautiful, sustainable relationship.
I've written about their love and its legacy a few times;hereorhere. As a loving unit they have given me a 'glass half full' view on love and marriage. They taught me that you can weather challenges and still find silver lining in a difficult situation. Through this they taught me that love isn't easy. You have to work for it. They stuck it out through good and bad, they learned each other and they made it work.My grandfather loved my grandmother. When we were going through their things after they had passed I found a few of these notes my grandmother had saved over the years. I keep them as atestamentto true, hard earned love. I miss them both dearly, I hope to honor them with my marriage and keeping their legacy alive. Alison

item.title: Alison Harper Style//At Home Masks For Happy & Healthier Hair
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
As you get close to your big event, there is a lot of prep involved. From eye brow waxes and tanning to getting your nails done. One thing I see overlooked is hair health. Most of the time brides-to-be have been growing their hair out for months, right before the wedding they get a very tiny trim so that they can keep all of the length in their hair. This combined with the fact that most soon to be brides are stressed and dieting; can lead to weak or lackluster locks. Don't worry girls, we've got two simple at home solutions for you! Try either recipe to fix you ailment and your hair will start to get healthier and happier by the treatment. Enjoy. xo
For Softer, Healthier Hair
Avocados are one of the only natural hair ingredients that can penetrate the hair cuticle, meaning that its softening abilities will stick around after you've rinsed this magic down the drain.
1/2 very ripe, mashed avocado 1/2 very ripe, mashed bananas 2 Tbsp of Olive Oil 1 eggPuree Banana and Avocado until no lumps are present. Mix in other ingredients. Apply to dry hair, cover with a shower cap or some other plastic wrap. Leave on for 30 minutes then wash hair. Follow with a nice conditioning shampoo and conditioner for even stronger results.
Photo Credit: Marie Claire
For Shinier, Healthier Hair
Apple Cider vinegar is another amazing kitchen ingredient. Its acidic properties will help clean off buildup on the hair shaft, while the oil will help add long lasting shine. Keep in mind if you have recently colored your hair to do this mask only once or twice as excessive use can dull color.
1 ripe banana 2 tsp. virgin coconut oil [or tea tree oil, avocado oil or olive in a pinch] 1 cup apple cider vinegarPuree Banana until no lumps are present. Mix in other ingredients. Apply to dry hair, cover with a shower cap or some other plastic wrap. Leave on for 30 minutes. Before shampooing, give a quick rinse with a bit more apple cider vinegar, then wash hair. Follow with a nice conditioning shampoo and conditioner for even stronger results.

item.title: Personal//Forever Flowers
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: People are full of advice, most importantly when it comes to your wedding. "Make sure to pick a good photographer", "Plated, not buffet".. it goes on. I heard so, so much about my flowers. -I had my own thoughts about my flowers. In fact, I was down right weird about my flowers. In all of my mental, pro-environment, obsessive wedding thoughts; I realized I didn't feel good about shipping thousand of cut flowers in the middle of February. I just couldn't deal with the eviro-foot print. I realize how crazy I sound. I decided that I wanted to have a fake flower bouquet. Yes, I do also realize how tacky that sounds. I wanted a silk flower bouquet. The other minimal amount of flowers could be real. I was fine with that. I wanted to feel good about my contribution to a better, greener wedding. My perfect wedding, in my own bizarre way. I argued with my mom; my grandmother had opinions; pretty much anyone I told put their nose up. I fought the good fight for my flowers. Just as I am sure any bride does, with at least one part of their wedding with their parents. For some reason this one little thing I wanted really irked people. Guess what, I 'm glad that I fought for this little tiny part of my wedding that I cared about. Besides, I now have my flowers forever.. and I think they look pretty good in my grandmother'sheirloom, Lenox vase in the middle of my dining room table. So pick what is important to you, no matter how absurd it may be. It is you and your husband's wedding and your memories. You wont regret it.

item.title: Personal//13 going on 30
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Last Saturday night, when I was curling up with my adored Netflix account I was feeling nostalgic. Scrolling the romcom section, I stumbled upon an old favorite. 13 going on 30 -Jennifer Garner. In all its 90s glory, chopsticks and fishnet chokers; its a story of a 13 year old girl who wishes she were an adult. In a very freaky-Friday moment she wakes up as a 30 year old magazine executive and realizes that it isnt all its cracked up to be. In the end its all love and happy. It just makes you wish you could give hard learned, life advice to yourself.
Dear 13 year old me, Hi. Its me. Yes, you. I just wanted to impart my new-found life experiences and drop a little knowledge on you. Here is my advice, Read as much as you can.When you get older, you wont have time to sit down and read for a whole day on the porch in the sunshine like you do now. Absorb it, read everything. Dont worry about missing anything. Reading can take you around the world and it will let you see things most people wont ever see. Learn to talk less.As you get older youll learn the wisdom to listen more and talk less. Sometimes you dont need to be heard, sometimes someone else needs you. When you talk less, you actually hear more.
Dont fight with Mom.You dont want to hear this but eventually youll be friends. You dont know this now, but you are really really similar. In fact your life will mirror hers. The things you might say now, will hurt her. Dont, just dont argue with her. She really does have your best interest at heart. Take yourself seriously.If you dont then no one will. You hear about those kids that graduate from Princeton at 14? You can do that. Truly, if you decide that there is something you want to do, just do it. You really dont understand this ability until youre in your mid 20s. You should know this earlier, you are completely capable. Learn to just be.One of the best things youll do is to learn to be alone. Unfortunately you dont learn this until youre in your mid 20s. Its a beautiful thing to watch the world. You learn a lot about yourself this way. Take a deep breath and watch the clouds pass by sometimes.
Everything will be fine.You are healthy, you have a loving husband and a beautiful family who will always help you back up. It will work out in the end. Just follow your path, trust that you are exactly where you are supposed to be right now. Just breath, Alison

item.title: Alison Harper Style//Bangs!
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
08/21/2013 7 Comments
In our last Industry tip post, we talked about how to pick theperfect haircut for your face shape. If you need to figure out your face shape visit our last posthere. Today, we're going to touch on whether you should take the plunge towards bangs or not. First things first, a few tips:
-NEVER cut your own bangs, in fact most salons offer free bang trims if you've gotten your hair cut with them. 9 times out of 10 if you attempt to cut your bangs, you'll end up with choppy or unevenness. -Your bangs will naturally lay better about a week after your cut. If you have anything important, say a wedding, get your hair cut at least a week before. -If you are really nervous about taking the jump, try out a add on piece.Any of these extension piecescan be just clipped in and snapped out. No commitment.
---------
Heavy Straight Bangs// Oval, Triangular or Long Shaped Face
Head over to our last post to figure out yourface shape.Straight, heavy bangs; often seen on Zooey Deschanel and rarely on the Taylor Swift can actually be worn by a few select fact shapes. Heart shaped or long face shapes are perfect for this blunt bang. By concealing the forehead and shortening the face it will help create a more chiseled jaw bone and present the illusion of an oval shaped face. People with oval shaped faces should avoid this style as it can sometimes appear overwhelming.
Soft Straight Bangs//Round, Square or Long ShapedFace
The lighter, softer sister to the straight and heavy bang above quite versatile. Bangs in this shape can be rounded or shorter in the center allowing the bangs to conceal face roundness or to shorten a face shape. These bangs are often seen on Glee's Lea Michelle or Hunger Games star Jennifer Lawrence. Softer, lighter, straight bangs are also a great introduction into the heavy, straight bangs if you are considering them.
Long Side Swept Bang//Square Shaped Face
Long, wispier side bangs are the perfect accent for a square face shape. Soft bangs like those pictured on Sandra Bullock and Nichole Richie below, cut across the square dimension bringing the eyes across diagonally versus horizontally. They help to soften the edges of this shape. Avoid short, sharp bangs as they can accentuate the squareness. Long side swept bangs can make a heart shaped or triangle shaped face appear longer. Long, side swept bangs are also the perfect introduction into bangs. They grow out quickly and can be pinned back easily.
Soft, short side bangs//Heart, Oval or Triangular Shaped Face
The slightly, shorter and soft side swept bang is a perfect accent to a heart or triangular shape. Luckily for the oval face shape these bangs don't overwhelm or shorten the face. These are easy to style but take a bit longer to grow out. Reese Witherspoon and the Olsen twins are perfect examples of soft, short, side swept bangs. Shorter hairstyles like the one Miley Cyrus is sporting are also flattering with their shorter fringe around the face.

item.title: Personal//Eye Contact
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
18 months ago, I sat in a white dress. Wringing my hands and counting the seconds until I could finally see you. I had been cooped up in that busy high school dressing room for far too long. Some one handed me a glass of champagne and I couldn't even drink it. I was so nervous. Not bad nervous, good nervous. I mean the nervous that still makes you want to throw up.. but good nervous none the less. With in the hour you were going to make me your wife. You were going to give me your last name and promise to keep me for the rest of your life.
We didn't really think about the logistics of it all, I was getting ready in the high school drama room attached to the stage. You had to walk through it to get out in front of our friends and family. It happened for a split second. You tried to keep your head down, all you had to do was make a quick left turn to go down the hall. You didn't. Just in that split second, you glanced up and found me. In that cheesy, dramatic, movie type of way; time stopped. We locked eyes. You gave me that little, tiny, brief smile. That one where just the right side of your lip goes up just a hint. Barelynoticeable.
In that moment, things calmed. My hands stopped shaking, my nerves stopped dancing. Peace, just peace. I knew. I knew it was right. In that moment everything settled. We weren't supposed to see each other; 'its bad luck.' We've heard it all. This was out of our hands, God just dropped this little reassurance in my lap, this little gift. Telling me that I was exactly where I was supposed to be in that moment. We've never discussed this, our families thinking our first look was at the altar. This was just our little moment. When time stopped for just us.

item.title: Personal//Perfection
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
I was grabbing sushi with a good friend of mine,Christinewhen we shared stories, recent struggles and victories. I was talking about how frustrating it is to work so hard on something to not have it work out perfectly whenshe said to me"Perfection equals death"I laughed at her melodramatic sentiment for a second when she stopped me.



"No really, have you ever had the perfect day? Once everything is perfect there is nothing left to strive for. When it has become perfect, there is no point to keep going."I've had this thought on my mind since our dinner. Perfection equals death. We are always busy trying to reach for perfect, but what happens when we finally get there? Replaying our conversation in my mind makes me a little more, okay with things not being completely perfect all the time.. I mean what else would I strive for if I reached it?

item.title: Alison Harper Style//Getting the perfect brow wax
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Unfortunately, we have all been there. In a quick hurry, you jet in to a new place for a clean up. You leave slightly irritated with really thin eyebrows. We've all been there. When leading up to a big event this can be a really big deal. Just like good skin, good eyebrows can help bring out your best features. Follow these simple tips to get the best eyebrow wax yet! xo
Please note! We always suggest planning any waxing or hair removal appointments at least 7-3 days before a big event.
Photo Credit:Brooke Courtney Photography
Aestheticiannot nail technician//
First of all, please know that this is not a knock to nail technicians education. Nail technicians are required to complete classes for 250 hours versus an aesthetic licence requires 600 hours. The focus of a nail technician's education is just that; nails. An aesthetician's education is focused around skin, skin care and hair removal. Any salon that offers facials, also offers skin care. The difference between the two is immeasurable, most nail salons you get a quick cookie cutter experience. A lot of times it is difficult to tell who is licensed and how clean the wax is.Where as in a salon setting you receive on average 15-20 minutes of your skin care therapists time. They have different options of wax, for different skin types, better lighting, better tools and they can take their time.
Do your research//
So you've made the decision to find an aesthetician for your waxing. Perfect! Now make sure to do the research needed. If you have any friends who have great brows ask around. Always make sure to check online reviews for a salon. They will give you the inside scoop on which employee is the better choice. Make sure to double check that your service provider is an actual aesthetician, occasionally if you are booking during a busy time they may schedule you with a nail technician or a hairstylist. Both are legally allowed to wax, but remember the idea is to get a specialist. Once you make your appointment, arrive 15 minutes early. They may need you to fill out a paper or two and you'll want to ensure that your skin care therapist has the entire window of time to dedicate to your eyebrows.
Let them grow//
This tip is a little challenging. Thankfully, the days of pencil thin brows are over. If you are just visiting an aesthetician for the first time, give it an extra week or two. It is best for your them to have a nice, full brow to shape. You will receive better results and your eye brows will grow in together, meaning your eyebrows wont be as unruly between sessions.
Photo Credit:Marcella Treybig Photography
Avoid certain medications//
Most people don't know this, but you should avoid certain medications almost 3 months prior to your waxing. Some of these medications can cause reactions, irritation and they can even cause your skin to peel off during a wax. Here is a basic list, but as always check with your doctor.
Adapalene,Alustra,Avage,Avita,Differin,Isotretinoin, Renova,RetinA,Tazarac,Tazarotene,Tretinoin
You will also want to pay attention to recent skin services you may have received. If you have had laser skin resurfacing, you'll need to wait 12 months before waxing. If you had a physician administered peel, you'll need to wait 24 months before waxing. Lastly, if you have a light chemical peel or microdermabrasion you'll need to give your skin 7 days before waxing.
Take care of your skin post wax//
This tip can be just as important as the set up for waxing. If you don't take care of your skin you can get irritation, redness, ingrown hairs and those pesky red bumps. Make sure to clean the area with mild soap when you get home. If your skin is irritated you can apply ice to reduce inflammation. If your skin is irritated you can apply a light layer of hydrocortisone cream. If your skin is calm a few hours after waxing, make sure to apply a good astringent followed by ice. Waxing can open your pores and to help reduce the chance of a break out later that will help.

item.title: Alison Harper Style//Getting the best haircut before a big event
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Whether you are coming up to the big day or have a hair cut or two between, follow these simple tips to help ensure you wont end up with a wedding day hair disaster! Often times we have clients who receive regular hair appointments but leading up to the wedding, they allow a bit more time between cuts. Whether you are allowing it to grow out, or just got busy; make sure to plan a haircut before the wedding day. It will make quite a difference in your hairstyle. Follow these tips and you'll be solid. xo
When// 2 weeks before event
2 weeks is the sweet, hair cut spot. Plan your cut and color accordingly. If you pay attention, usually a week after your fresh haircut, your cut starts to settle and looks its best. This is really important if you get bangs, after a week they lay better. On the flip side, you want to make sure that you don't go over 2 weeks if you get highlights or color. The only thing worse than having dead ends on your wedding day is having grown out color. So stick with two weeks and you'll be golden. Or brunette, or cool blond, or red..
Be Choosy// Don't skimp and Don't assume
First off, if you have a current stylist and you like like their work; stick to them. However if you weren't too excited about your last appointment you should do a little research and try someone new. Make sure that this person is well reviewed, has ample appointment time to see you and that you are comfortable with this person. Just because it is your wedding day doesn't mean you should have to go out to the most expensive salon in town to get the perfect look. On the flip side, you'll need to pay a moderate amount to get a decent amount of time with your stylist. Choose wisely!
Pay Attention// No streaky highlights
This tip is usually something no one thinks about. If you are getting highlights make sure to talk with your stylist about how you are wearing your hair for the wedding day. If your stylist is in a hurry, they may end up putting thick or uneven highlights around or near your face. When your hair is done, you'll want to pull it back as if in a pony tail and inspect your hairline. There will be a small amount of space from the scalp but around your hair line shouldn't look grown out or streaky. If for some reason you do end up with these results, do not hesitate to say something. Most stylists are willing to fix something if you aren't happy. If they push back, ask to speak with a manager. This isn't unreasonable and this is really important.
Bangs or not // Don't get wild
This is a little bit of common sense. If you have bangs, then get them trimmed as usual. If you are thinking about bangs and have never had them, you may want to wait. We don't suggest that you ever try anything severely different or trendy leading up to the wedding. Classic, remember?
Set up your Stylist for Success// Photos and timing
If you want to get the best service possible, you'll want to set your stylist up for success. When you set your appointment ask the receptionist when your stylist is least busy. If you make an appointment on a Saturday, expect to be a little hurried. Your stylist may have a full book of appointments and wont have the extra time to discuss highlight placement. If you plan a week day appointment, don't come right before the salon closes. This may not always be true, but your stylist may be tired. Imagine if you were asked to do something really important the last 15 minutes of your work day, its not going to get done with the same zeal as if you had been asked when you first came in. Make sure that you are early to your appointment, nothing is more frustrating to a stylist than having their entire day delayed because of one appointment. Remember, you'll want your stylist happy, refreshed and excited. Bring pictures too. Having a photo or two of your color or cut will help the stylist to get into your brain and understand exactly what you want. There are thousands of shades of blonde and occasionally you two could be on different pages entirely.
Helpful things to think about//
Always follow the advice of your wedding day updo stylist. In my experience, a hair cut with layering is always best. If you are planning on wearing your hair half up or half down, layering will help to get the cascading waves that you may be looking for. Colored hair will also hold curl a little better than natural. Just make sure you plan for a successful haircut and you wont be disappointed. If for some reason you are left unhappy, don't hesitate to say something. You are a paying client and it is your big day!

item.title: Alison Harper Style//Operation Homefront
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
On Thursday we had the privilege to pamper some very special mom's to be. We are a part of the DC chapter ofNACE, the National Association of Catering and Events. NACE partnered withOperation Homefront, a charity organization that helps military families in need. This moving event was hosted to pamper 50 military mom's that needed a little extra support. The moms were able to enjoy breakfast a little free baby shopping, hair and makeup by our team and free bump photos! After the pampering session, they had a delicious lunch, a few give aways and a pretty sweet surprise. Each mom received a bundle of baby items as well as a free Nuna stroller. It was such a sweet moment, we honored families who have given so much to each of us. I couldn't think of a more moving way to give back.
After the event, the planning team received a lovely note from one of the moms:
"I keep tearing up thinking how grateful I was to be a part of this event today. I hope everyone knows how much things like this are appreciated and I hope to one day be able to give back to Operation Homefront as much as ya'll have done for my family. It is nice to know that people still love the military and love helping the Service Member and their families. I can never express how much this organization means to me and how much you personally have changed many situations in my life."
I am truly honored that we were able to help support this cause and these women. I know that hair and makeup can be taken and washed off, but I am so glad that over all we were able to provide a few niceties to these women who deserve so much more. I want to make sure I highlight the amazing sponsors who gave to this event. I don't have a list but hopefully this picture will do the trick. xo
If you are looking to give, Operation homefront is an amazing charity that can always use giving individuals and sponsors. They have call to action needs that indviduals or bigger groups can help. Please visit them athttp://www.operationhomefront.net/dcmetro/ to see how you can help today.

item.title: Personal//This is the year
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
This is the year of high thread count sheets and better work-life balance. Ofextra long dinners over wine, planning week long trips to anywhere but here. This is the year of finally understanding my worth, high heeled wedges and more expensive facial moisturizer. The time for less investment in what others think. The year of cooking nights with my husband, counting my blessings and perfume instead of body spray. The year I work on accepting that I am exactly where I am supposed to be. Of guiltless pumpkin spice lattes and regular pedicures.The year I'm going to finally invest in those really amazing faux-leather cropped pants I want so, so bad. This is the year of coffee and sun rises, of those few extra minutes of cuddling and trusting myself to fall for my husband over and over again. This is the year, and this is my year. Happy Birthday to me.
Caitlin and I in our faux-iphone-80's-glamour shot by Anna Bruce Photography.

item.title: Personal//Easy Goes
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: I went online a few days ago and I saw a pretty well known planners photo with her husband. The quote below "Marriage is easy" My first reaction, I thought 'oh that's sweet.' Before I got really bothered by the statement. The more I thought about it, the more bothered I was. Marriage isn't easy. For anyone. Ever. Yes, it has its beautiful, slow parts where things fall in place well, but it also has its struggles. Two humans are learning to cohabitate, they are from different backgrounds, different upbringings and have different thought patterns. Naturally, there are going to be adjustment periods, compromise and frustration. I just wanted to put one thing out into the cyber world to combat that theory, that if you are in a rough spot, adjusting and fighting for your marriage that you are doing something wrong. You are not, marriage isn't easy. It is a constant battle in which love wins. Jd and I are doing well, he supports me I care for him. He is my partner in life, I will always have his back and he will always be there holding my hand. Guess what, we've fought through some things. Its a constant growing thing, marriage. I just wanted to put that out there. If your marriage isn't easy right now, that's okay. Fight for this beautiful thing. xo

item.title: Personal//Support
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Today, my team and I are getting geared up for a fabulous shoot at the Corcoran Gallery of Art in DC. Before I run out of the door and into the city I just wanted to take a quick moment to reflect. The other morning, I was rushing, huffingly late. Before I could slam the door behind me, Jd had made me an egg sandwich. The gesture stunned me. With how overwhelmed I've been with things of late, the fact that he got out of bed before the sun came up, snuck and made the eggs while I showered and then surprised me with a breakfast I was about to skip.. it was just too much. If I hadn't been running so late, I would have probably cried. I posted of facebook that afternoon asking what your person does to support you. The responses were so simple, yet so sweet. I just had to share them. It was such a beautiful testament to the fact that love can come in the simplest of forms. Love is an everyday, rudimentary task. Love is a hug from the back while cooking dinner, a car wash or an egg sandwich. I couldn't help myself and I'm sorry if I'm embarrassing anyone. I hope though, that this brightens your day a little, like it did mine.
xo

item.title: Personal//Monday Inspiration
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
We all have those days, we roll over and get up. While we get up, we don't actually wake up. I've been having a series of these days, we all have them. The fog of sleep never left my brain, I'm running on neutral and no amount of coffee can undo the lack of umpf I have. These days are okay, no one can be fully on 100% of the time. The key with having a day or two like this is to focus on climbing out. Whenever I feel this way, thankful less and less often as I get older; I decide to get inspired. The best way for me to climb out a funk is to get my brain pumping. When you are feeling this way, inspiration is everywhere yet you can miss it. So on this lovely Monday morning, I want to inspire you. If you are feeling lackluster, here is a list of things that inspire me and places I gain inspiration from.
Music//
There is something about getting my groove on that helps clear the fog for me. I love music and the poetry behind the lyrics stays with me all day.
"Feeling my way through the darkness Guided by a beating heart I can't tell where the journey will end But I know where to start They tell me I'm too young to understand They say I'm caught up in a dream Well life will pass me by if I don't open up my eyes So wake me up when it's all over When I'm wiser and I'm older All this time I was finding myself And I didn't know I was lost" -Avicii
Instagram//oliphantstudio
This studio has an active instagram chock full of stunning images. Annie Leibovitz and others, Icould stare at them for hours. I follow maybe 15 artists on instagram.
Vouge//
Always a source of inspiration for me is Vouge. I could just sift through the ads and feel like I've touched something beautiful. It works for me everytime.
In case you cant find your sources here are a few things that spoke to me today. Happy Monday, go take over the world. xo

item.title: Real Wedding//Stephanie & Kyle
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Stephanie and Kyle were married in a extraordinary way here in DC. They had their hearts set on their friend Scott marrying them. He became ordained, plans were made and then due to some difficult Virginia laws; he wasn't allowed to marry them at their venue. So what did they do? They had a super intimate mini ceremony during their first look, just the two of them. This way they could have the best of both worlds, a sweet private ceremony officiated by their good friend and then a larger, slightly more legal one for family and friends. Each tiny detail was thought through. It was a beautiful wedding. I just can't wait for you to see Stephanie's reactions. She had some of the best faces! Congrats to you both for not only taking this massive leap into marriage but for doing it your own way. The best way for the both of you. xo

item.title: Personal//Happy Day
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Today, our very beautiful office manager gets married. I have been lucky enough to consider Katy my dear friend. She was the first artist we added to our team and she has grown with my company and has worked along side me on this amazing dream I have. I could not be more thankful to have her on my side. Today I get to attend the wedding of Katy and her fiancee Ronnie. Words cannot describe how excited I am for the two of them.
Dear Katy, I cannot tell you how happy I am that you have found someone like Ronnie. The two of you are a perfectly molded match. You two have taught me things about my own marriage and are a beautiful example of respect, support and love. I am so happy to get to watch you walk down the aisle today. This day has been a long time coming. I am thinking of the two of you today and hoping for you both a lifetime of happiness, compromise and laughter. As always, I am full of advice you didn't ask for. I just wanted to say a few thoughts that were given to me on my wedding day. Marriage, as I am learning is like a small plant. If you leave it unattended and un-cared for it will wither and die. Eventually you will remove the decomposed plants' roots from your garden only to look for a new plant to fill the void. If you care for it, give it attention. Trim it, water it and talk to it -it will become the most beautiful, and full plant in your garden. It will bloom with beautiful flowers, produce vegetables. It will provide you with everything that you need, shade and food. As the old adage goes, the grass is green where you water it. I know that you and Ronnie will succeed. You have so many people rooting for the two of you. It is so exciting to see such raw, tangable love like I see between you two. I am sorry that this is so long, as I venture into overly creepy. I just wanted you to know that my heart is full for you today and I am excited for you and where this life will lead you. xo

item.title: Alison Harper Style//Short Hair Styling
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Having short hair can sometimes prove to be a challenge when trying to compile your wedding day look. This post, is for my shorties. A little short, sweet updo inspiration. xo
Julianne Hough at the golden globes, twisted and pinned her hair back to give the illusion of longer hair. With a little volume on top and soft twisted sides. Perfect for someone who has a short, chin length bob haircut.
Photo Credit: People.com
This hairstyle, referred to as a Gibson Tuck is another short hair illusion trick. By tucking the ends up into a twist it gives the idea that there is more hair. For this style the front pieces of your hair by your ear should be able to reach back in to a very small pony tail.
Photo Credit: The Knot
Simple, yet effective is a classic standby. Soft curls and a side pulled up. This is perfect for someone who embraces their short hair and wants to show of those fabulous earrings!
Photo Credit: Pinterest
This sideways, french braid style is a good choice for someone with a lot of layering in their haircut. It can be full, secure and it also gets your hair up off of your face. For this style, your hair should be in a slightly longer bob hair cut.
Photo Credit: WeddingGoal.com
Faith Hill rocks the short hair and adores volume. This simple, classic standby is a great style for someone who likes a simpler style and embraces their hair length. With a sleeker style like this you can pull of a more dramatic makeup application or more dramatic jewelry.
Photo Credit: Pinterest
Keep in mind, if you have a pixie cut you can generally carry a much more dramatic hair accessory. Seen below, is a short, cropped cut with a stunning accessory. This is perfect for someone who loves their cut and wants to proudly show it off. You go, shorty.
Photo Credit: Pinterest

This, this..tragedyhas happened to such an amazing set ofparents.It pulls on my heart.Gabby was born prematurely and fought her entire life.This young angel graced us for only a short time and her little life has touched so many people. item.title: Personal//Compromise
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Just two nights ago, my husband and I had a full blown, political style vote in our living room. He wanted football, I wanted Christmas music and ornaments. He wanted to order pizza and I wanted warm, southern style food. We were on two very different tracks for our evening whenI turned to him.
"Okay, while I make meatloaf and mash potatoes, you can watch the game." He responded "While you make meatloaf, I'll set a fire in the fireplace." I nodded, "Okay, when I'm done in the kitchen you can watch your game with the volume turned downandwe can play Christmas music in the background."
We proceeded to negotiate how many times he was aloud to yell at the TV over Bing Crosby. It was a heated debate of giving and taking a little. I know that this doesn't sound like much, or it sounds insane to you. Either way, this was a pivotal move for us. Compromise is when two sides meet a mutual agreement. In most cases, until the great Christmas tree debate of 2013; one of us has just given to the other. Its selfless and beautiful but restricting and frustrating to have a marriage like that. There can be guilt in getting your way and there can be resentment in stepping aside. Like this very juvenile negotiation, we are learning to exercise our give and take, flexing those muscles at the same time. It was beautiful. In the end I shamelessly sung my off key version of Mariah Carey's Christmas album while he occasionally gazed off at the silent tv with an ornament in his hand.Better than last yearand perfect for us.

item.title: Personal//Similarly Different
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
This Tuesday morning, we're going to get real personal. Like, meet my shoe collection personal. As I'm growing in my marriage, I'm learning that life is long. That things are not perfect. People are not perfect. No one told me when I picked out that white dress howchallengingbeing married could be.

Let meclarifythat I would not change a second of it. I love my husband, even with all of hisidiosyncrasies. Like using two dryer sheets instead of one. [One can do the job. Two is a waste. Seriously.] As we grow I amrealizing that it isn't how alike we are, or how much we parade our likeness. We're different. Very different. Sometimes that is the biggestchallenge Understanding him and he getting me. I was laying in bed one morning when I realized the symbolism of our pair of closets.

Meet our closets; a view from my very comfortable memory foam.
I warned you it would get personal.
His & Hers

From the outside, they look alike. An adorable matching pair. Clean simple doors, matching handles. Even. Similar. On the inside however, well, not so much.

My husband is quiet, driven, clean. Hard working. Simple. Not simple like stupid. He'sdefinitelynot stupid. Simple like basic. Simple like put him on an island with a pack of matches and he'll get all 'Bear Grylls' on you. Simple. Strong.

I'm a bit more of an extrovert. I don't like when people don't like me. I can get loud, talkative. I don't think I owned a pair of tennis shoes until our hiking trip around Arizona. I'm melodramatic and complicated -in a sweet way. I think.

His & Hers

We're different. When he buys a new shirt, he throws one away. He owns 3 colored shirts. In the bottom of his closet he has 3 pairs of shoes. 3 baskets for dry cleaning, dress socks and white gym socks.

My closet is anexplosionof color. [I actually cleaned up the floor of it for you] There is organization in there. somewhere. That is a basket of high heels. I keep my winter, summer in there. I've got scarves, purses, riding helmets and nail polish. In fact, those board games and bag full of purses you see in my husbands closet? I put those there.

This is a very clear symbol of the difference in our personalities, living style, approach to all of it. We're different. At our core, we different. Somehow we click though. My stuff magically spills into his closet at times. On the rare occasion that I dolaundry, I put his clothing back just how he likes it. I respect the basket rule and he doesn't complain that I have three pair high heels that look practically the same.

Even though we are so different we are learning to accept each others quirks. We respect each other, we make it work. There is a balance to it. I swear. I'm not sure why I am sharing this. Maybe in hopes to show that there is challenge to marriage. There is work, differences and acceptance. It isn't candy corn and rainbows. It can be happy and rewarding and you don't have to be alike. You can be different.

item.title: Alison Harper Style//Time
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
I don't have spare time. At all. I have a gym membership I haven't used in 3 months. I made my husband microwave his own frozenburritolast nightbecauseI didn't have time to make dinner. [To his horror.] I just don't have a spare minute to myself. I'm a hungry small business owner. I have to force myself to relax at times and carve out an evening with my ladies. I just don't have extra. Really any where.

When Karen Buck of wedding 411 emailed me and asked if My ladies and I would be willing to donate our time and talent for this cause I knew I couldn't say no. You know that saying"Everyone, knows someone affected by breast cancer"Well. Its true. I haven't suffered from this life stealing disease but it has touched my life in a distant way.


My mother has nine siblings. One of my aunts married my solid, gregariousCubanuncle. He had a sister. When I was young she and my mom were close friends. She rented the basement apartment of my parents house. Her children were raised side by side with my siblings and I. In fact you could hear her yelling "I used to change your diapers!!!" at me at Christmas parties.

She was a loud, vivacious, funny and a loyal woman. She was diagnosed with breast cancer right around her second daughters birth over 17 or so years ago. She fought, she had surgeries, she had treatments.She won.She raised twosuccessfuland beautiful daughters. Until this year. The cancer came back. It came back with avengeance. She fought. She fought hard but she didn't win.

Although it has been a few years since her daughters and I had sleep overs, birthday parties and truth or dare challenges. This loss has touched me. She was a really great mom.She lost her life to a cancer that we should have a cure for.She left behind two brilliant daughters and a whole family of people who love her.

I know this is far fetched and may be crazy talk, but when I was asked if I would cut out time for this event I couldn't say no. I needed to do this for me. I needed to do this, because in some far off way... theproceeds from this event couldhelp a family from losing their mother, sister, cousin or friend. I coulddefinitelycut out time for this.


Last night a few of our Alison Harper ladies and I traveled out to the Maryvale Castle for the Brides Against Breast Cancer Cinderella event. It was an awesome fashion show and really fun. We worked along side other hair and makeup teams, updos for i dos, fresh faces by Cindy. A ton of local vendors, charm city cakes, gala cloths all donated their time. Even if we raised one dollar it was worth it.

The event is also happening tonight. There is still time if you'd like to attend. We'd love to see you, when we do it all again.Click here for more information.



Decor and accessories! That is a cake!



Journey and Jen hard at work



Models & Dresses.



Jen, Journey and I after a long hard evening of beautiful people.

item.title: Alison Harper//Building a Team
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
As part of my new business blog series I promised to discuss building and maintaining a team. I know that this is a pretty hot button issue for most artists. Its a scary little jump, how do you trust someone else out on their own? How do you make sure they don't steal your business.. the list goes on. Here are some helpful tips when deciding to add to your army.


1. Make sure you are ready to have a team.
Sit back and really think about this one. Once you start to add, there really isn't any going back. Yes, it may add to your profit and help build your business name but it will almost immediately double your work load. Make sure that you are at a point where you really can release some of the work to someone else and that when they are trained properly that you are mentally ready to let them do it on their own. [I'm talking to you, type-a-ers]

2. Get your paperwork set up.
Once you've decided to get going contact your lawyer, accountant and insurance provider. Depending on your state [each are different] you will want to have some type of contract written up. Your lawyer can handle that and tell you in about 15 minutes the next steps needed, legally. Your insurance provider will need to update your coverage. My insurance didn't even change in price when I started a team and had under 3 other artists.


Gabriela hard at work with our bride Moina

3. Start hiring.
I am always hiring. I will hire even if I don't have work for someone [I will make sure to tell them that! -ha]. I never want to turn down talented, driven artists. I am always "hunting" [as my mom calls it] If my grocery bagger mentions that her little sister just finished hair school, like clockwork you'll hear "Is she looking for a job?"My best artists come fromreferrals or hunting. Ask around. I will trust a friend of a friend before I'll ever trust Craigslist [not to knock it, craigslist has someawesomefinds and isn't a bad idea if you are new to the area].

When you do come across someone you may think to hire, do an interview! I know that this sounds like a nobrainierbut I can't tell you how many small business owners don't! They feel like its a bitpretentiousto bringsomeoneinto your home office to interview. Don't think this way. If you start off on the professional foot, your artists will carry that through. When you interview ask to see their work, skill set and resume.

4. Let them know what they are in for.
The best policy when dealing with a staff/team/group is honesty. Be clear with them on payment expectations, work load and your expectations. You will get a lot farther with honesty. When I started with a team we had 3 weddings booked a month. I laid it out honestly, surprisingly the girls stuck around because they believed in what I was doing and knew that eventually it would be successful.

Also, people are not mind readers. You have to put every thing on paper. Everything. People have different versions of professionalism. You may think all black, with slacks, close toed shoes and hair and makeup done is "dressing professionally"; the new makeup artist you hired might think that her silver bra straps that match her flip flops is "dressing professionally."


Katy hard at work with our bride Amanda
Photo credit:Darling Photographers

I hope that this helps a few of you looking to branch out. Please leave me some feedback if there is something you'd prefer to hear about!


Look for our next Business Post about Contracts!

item.title: Personal//Nate & Jacob
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Disclaimer: I don't normally get political, I feel that everyone is entitled to your opinion. However, this is afundamentalliberty that should be offered to everyone. It hits very close to home to my family and I. I apologize -if this offends you, then you should stop reading.


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------


I wont ever forget hearing the story of Nate and Jacob. I was working in a small salon in College Park when the stylist next to meleaned over with a look in her eyes and said "I have no idea what to tell him." I sat and listened as she cut his hair, speechless. What do you say in this situation?What can you say?

Nate was an older gentleman, slight, friendly, calm with a little grey hair. I'd seen him come to Lynn for trims every two weeks like clock work. He always had a soft smile and otherwise, you didn't hear much from him. As I satlistening, Idiscoveredhis struggles. I wasappalled. It turns out that he and his partner had been together for 27 years. When his partner was diagnosed with Stage IV cancer, his death had come quickly and quietly. It had spread from his prostate, to stomach and a few other organs before they were able to even know what had hit him.

As sad as that was there was another series of blows Nate would have to endure. While watching the love of his life pass into a coma he discovered the limitations he would suffer. You see,Nate and Jacob weren't able to marry. In Jacobs lifetime same-sex marriages were barely legal inMassachusetts.Apparently, Jacobs very small andestrangedfamily hadn't spoken in decades. His few living relatives having been out of touch which left only his partner Nate. Unfortunately, since by law Nate and Jacob weren't married [or next of kin], Jacob died alone in a hospital bed while Nate had to wait in the waiting room.



Yes, you heard that correctly. Nate was sipping cold vending machine coffee in the waiting room while his partner of 27 years passed behind hospital room doors. No one was holding Jacobs hand, Nate didn't really get to say good bye. It only gets worse from here. Since Nate didn't have the best credit, their house was in Jacobs name and the cars were in Nate's name. Which means, you guessed it. After loosing his lifepartner he was also ordered to leave his home. Anything that was considered Jacob's, went to his estranged family in Idaho. Since they were not married, Nate was not entitled to any of his life insurance policy or socialsecuritysurvivor benefits.

So now Nate, without his partner; after losing his home and a significant portion of his house hold incomehad to start over at 56.

What do you say to someone in this situation? What do you say? Sorry? I'm sorry your partner passed so unexpectedly. I'm sorry that you weren't able to spend the last moments with them?I'm sorry that you aren't protected?

No amount of 'I'm Sorry' would help Nate. What would have helped Nate, would have been the ability to say good by to his partner, the ability to plan Jacobs funeral, the protection of his rights. That would have fixed it.
----------------------------------------------------------------


Its too late to help Nate and Jacob. However, I ask that each of you strongly consider voting today and supporting Question 6. Gender equality has come a few short steps since Jacobs passing but not far enough. There are now a few small safe gaurds protecting these couples but there is still so far to go. It is up to us to stand up and support people like Nate, to help fight for their basic human rights.

My mother and youngest brother

On a more personal note; my hope is that one day I will wear a bridesmaid dress, walk down the aisle and toast my brilliant younger brother and his future husband. My hope is that when that day comes, he will have the exact same rights, protections and security that I currently have with my husband. Marriage is a very sacred thing and I strongly believe that this is a right we should afford to everyone. This cause hits very close to home for me and my family. Please use your right to vote to help others have the same rights.



Defend Marriage Equality,Vote for Question 6.
