item.title: Alison Harper Style//Bridesmaid's Gifts
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Photo: Michelle Lindsey Photography


What do you get your closest gal pals? The ones who've helped you glue 200 little ribbons onto little mini jar favors. The ladies who helped plan the most memorable bachelorette party. [-They even remember the sash]. The girls who bought the dress, the shoes, the plane ticket. The ladies who listen for months while you rattled on about linens, registries and your mother in law. I think the bridesmaids deserve a little more credit.

Their role starts long before that sweet beautiful walk down the aisle. I think they deserve a thoughtful, lovely, little treat for still being your friend after that one bridezilla moment. Here are some ideas.

I love these personalized clutches. They can match their dress and they can use them again! They can be found ingirlbyAileenShop on etsy. You can even write a little message to them on the tag!


Apparently personalizingis all the rage. These little tumblers are so cute. The nice part, you can make the dresses your color and add their name! These can be found inGetItPersonalizedshop on etsy.



I've seen similar shirts. I think they are a fabulous idea. Better yet, these have a lace razor back. Super adorable. They can be found inBrideBikiniShop on Etsy.



Like an adult version of the tumbler cups these champagne glasses can also be personalized with their name and dress color. Perfect for those morning of toasts! They can be found onWaterfallDesignsEtsy shop. One of our super classy brides, Mariel gave them to her ladies.
Photo by Marcella Treybig Photography



Jewelryis always a great go to for bridesmaids. There are tons of options. I guess if we are sticking to the 'personalizing' trend this is a great option. I just love the quote! These can be found onOtisBWeddingsetsy shop.


If your friends are at all like my friends these flasks would be a hit. Seriously. A hit. I'll just leave it at that. You can find these super classy flasks atEmilysEmporium1. Bonus, you can get matching groomsmen gifts!


Photo: Rachel Foster Photography

Out of all of these things. The most thoughtful and personal gifts would be the treat of a little pampering. [I had to say it] We are experts at making people feel beautiful, so the sweetest gift of all is a morning of papering. Make your girls feel gorgeous, treat them to a service.

xo,
Alison

item.title: Personal//1 Year
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
It was a busy crazy Saturday. One of the last days of our season with more than 7 weddings. I was exhausted. I carried my tired little tail up the two flights of steps into our brand new condo. I was so tired I didn't even notice the trail of little pine needles crunching under my boots. I opened the door with a sigh and what to my wondering eyes should appear?


A Fiance smiling proudly next to a naked, 5 footDouglasfir.


I slammed the door -crying and locked myself in the bathroom. In this moment, I was so so very upset. Doesn't he know that this was supposed to be our first Christmas tree? We were supposed to bundle up in sweaters. Rubbing our gloves together we were supposed to pace the safeway parking lot, examining each tree carefully. We were supposed to decide together which tree was not too tall, not too fat. We. We were supposed to tie it to the roof, wrestle it up the stairs. We were supposed to set it up together. I would stand back with my hot chocolate and watch him put it in the stand, telling him to move it left then right. Together. We were supposed to do this together.

Dashed. All of it. Our Christmas card, moment. I know this sounds dramatic. I'm not arguing that, besides -I was exhausted. It was just that in my family, it was a tradition. To pick it out and set it up together. So I cried. He knocked on the bathroom door, confused.

I finally let him in and told him. We fought. Not a crazy fight, a confused fight. Neither of us understood each other. Eventually we decorated our poor lonely tree.

I look back at that moment and I relish in it. That beautiful,pivotalmoment. It was one of those fights that only new couples have. I didn't realize that in his family the man went out in the cold and picked the sturdiest, fullest tree on the lot. He strapped it to his roof carried it home like a proud hunter. The ladies 'oooed' and 'awwed' sipping their hot chocolate while the men labored during set up. I didn't know that. -I just didn't know that.

I cried and ruined his proud manly moment. I didn't know. It was one of those things that you learn about someone after you live with them for a while. We were new. We were new at all of this. We were new with each other.




It has been about a year since that argument and it has been a interesting ride. I am not sure why I am sharing this. I just know now that this is normal. I didn't know then that this was normal. We're going to fight, we're going to have moments.

This is being married.


We tried it our own way this year. He picked out the tree, brought it home and I helped him set it up. Then we both admired our gorgeous full tree. It wasn't glamorous. It didn't look like a holiday card but we did it our own way.
It was perfect.

xo,
Alison

item.title: Personal//Have Enoughs
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Growing up without a lot was a constant game of "have enough." Watching other kids in their new back to school cloths with fancy Christmas gifts, family vacations. After years of envy I had to learn to weigh value in the personal. I have more unconditional love then most. I did lack but what I lacked was made up for in support, laughter and that indescribable feeling of complete acceptance by those around me.

Lately I've been really caught up with the "have enough." I heard a quote that grabbed it right from my brain. The one above this paragraph. It's so easy to do that. All anyone puts out there is only their very best. It's difficult to not compare all the things your read about all the things on Facebook, instagram or blogs. I just need to remember that I am blessed beyond measure. I have a loving and supportive husband. No, if I'm being honest -he may not stare deep in my eyes and tell me every thought on his mind. No he doesn't send me flowers or write me poems. No, but he shows me in his steady day to day actions. I have a sparky, brilliant dog who somehow wanders in at just the right moment to tug at my heart. I have a beautiful, sweet mother who is always just a phone call away. Literally. I have the most involved and caring siblings.


More than any one human deserves.
Lovely photo of Jd I by my friendChristine Barker Photography

I have a business that I truly feel has a purpose. It is bigger than me. I get the joy of liberating artists from their 40 hour. I get to give women who have never felt it, hope that they could provide for their family. We get to celebrate and make women feel beautiful on a day. This is one of the most important missions.

Not that overly preyed on"biggest day of your life."Truly, I think that day is reserved for when you welcome your first born. We get to be a part of a day that is so privately important between to people. We help boost a woman's confidence on her mostvulnerableday. We help to make her feel comfortable in that big dress, in front of anyone she knows. We help her feelconfidentwhile she bares her heart and publicly acknowledges her trust and care to another person. We get to be a part of that.


How can you place value on such things? How can I compare those things?
I am blessed beyond what any human deserves.

Xo,
Alison

item.title: Real Wedding//Victoria & JD
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
A little while back, I spoke with Victoria about her wedding. I almost fell out of my chair when she told me her would be husband was called 'JD'. Which, creepily enough is what we call my husband. It took all I had to not yell out "HUSBANDnameTWINS!! Canwebebestfriends?!"

We talked a little more about her husband and it turned out that they met when he was anexchangestudent from Spain in the 90's. She wanted to make sure that their weddingencompassedboth their cultures since both families would be meeting at the wedding. The guests were traveling from all over the world. It turned out beautifully. They each said their vows in the others native language. They had an intimate ring warming ceremony, where the guests could bless their rings and the ceremony was bilingual.

The neatest thing about their wedding was that they had their own private ceremony on New years eve and eloped. This wedding was their way of honoring their friends and families and bringing it all together. IrememberVictoria telling me how happy she was that they did it this way, it took away all of the pressure and jitters so she could just enjoy the day.

Thank you toYasmina Cowanfor sharing these beautiful photographs of their day. We were so excited that their wedding was featured onUnited with Love!
Enjoy,
Alison

item.title: Real Wedding//Sarah & Jon
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Sarah emailed us a few months before her wedding. I had to do a double take. We had another wedding on the same day, 2 blocks away and the bride had the same last name. I asked her if she was related, which she replied.. no. So being the private-eye that I am, asked again. No. Shereassuredme. This was the beginning of ourcorrespondence. I could not have started on a better foot.


Sarah was laid back, classic and quite funny. I mean being kate-middleton beautiful doesn't hurt either. The morning of her wedding she was getting ready in one of the most beautiful hotels in Alexandria. The group of women she celebrated the morning with were equally relaxed. Normally when we walk into a hotel room there is a buzz. Sometimes it is on fire, electric with everyone jumping around. Music pumping, bridesmaids snapping pictures and the bride near tears.


This morning was different. Sarah answered the door coffee cup in hand, in her flowy wrap dress "Good morning! A few of my friends will be here soon" Cool, calm and collected. She wanted a simple, classic look. A "I could have done this myself if I were really talented" kind of look. She just wanted to look beautiful for her husband, like her. Speaking of her husband, Jon.. anytime you asked Sarah a question about Jon her eyes lit up. Not in a teary eyed fairytale way, but in an I'm-completely-ready-to-spend-my-life-with-him way. If you ask me that is way better than fairytale tears. I wont walk you through all of this and talk the whole time, I'll just let you see for yourself. Complete happiness for a couple so meant to be together.



I'd like to thank Sarah for letting us be a part of her morning. I hope you had the most memorable day. I'd also like to thank our friends over atflutterphotoyou can find themhere. We've worked with them before, and they take really awe inspiring pictures. Until next time!
xo,
Alison

item.title: Personal//So Last Night......
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
So. Yeah, last night. I went to a little area industry party put on by the knot. Last year, although I was an advertiser; Iapparentlydid not make the cut. Basically I wasn't invited, because in case you were curious.. you had to be invited. I know, fancy -right? Well nothing makes you feel like the smelly kid in class like not being invited to a party that everyone you know will be at. Imagine my glee, I use the word glee because that is the only way to describe the way I shook my fists in joy when I got the invite.


Finally! I get to rub elbows with those people the knot thinks are awesome! I'm in. etc. etc.. It was beautiful. I walked in and it was an enchanted forest! They gave you gift bags, there were cupcakes with glitter on them.Edibleglitter. It was beautiful, classy, inspirational and just what I imagined. I realized something last night. I mean it was a beautiful party, but as looking around the room at the beautiful decor, I was holding my pink champagne with the rock candy stirrer, grinning like my life depended on it and pretending my feet didn't hurt -I realized something. It started to click with me that there are some people that I want to align my business with, my goals with and my friendship with and some that I don't. I know that may sound simple and kind of "a-duh?" moment as I like to call it, it actually clicked in a real life situation. I looked around the group I was standing in and I realized a few of the other vendors were in it for the wrong reasons. Irealized, "I don't like what you stand for. You aren't doing this for the right reasons and you don't treat your staff very well" Point blank, "you're just not that nice."


Which of course made me think more about, what do I stand for? Why do I do this? What is my purpose? Am I nice? [There is something about rock candy that makes me allphilosophical. oh and yes, I'm nice.] I am still chewing on that, because I feel like the answers to these questions are not easy, simple ones. I do know this, I do this because I am passionate about women feeling beautiful, relaxed and pampered. I do this for that moment when the bride slips her veil on and her Momshedsa tear. I get to be a part of that. Not many people get to have such amazing moments at work. Iappreciatemy artists, without them this wouldn't even be possible and I genuinely love what I do. This is why I do what I do and now I know I amconsciousof the fact that I want to surround my self and my business with others who feel like I do.

item.title: Personal//A little perspective
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
I remember it like a it was yesterday. Not actually like yesterday, because I occasionally forget what I wore yesterday. I remember it like it was a really intense dream. I was wearing sweats in case you were curious. I was a high school freshman. A high school freshman with mono.A high school freshman with mono in sweats.

For days, -eternity- I couldn't move from the couch. The tv was too far away, the couch was too small and it was way too hot in my mothers cluttered living room. First I was cold, then I was colder. Then I was hot. With the little voice I had, I complained.I whined like a typical teenager. I was tired andachyand I felt clammy and I couldn't decide if I was hungry. I whined and complained when my mom wouldn't pay me enough attention, like she could magically rid me of the symptoms. I wheezed and I couldn't believe my luck.

Here I am, exhausted. Barely able to move from my moderately temperate couch, barely able to keep down a veryvegetarian homemadebroth my mom made. Barely able to bear this temporary disease. I couldn't believe I was missing class, my friends. Missing cheerleading practice -man, at this rate I willprobablymiss the football game this weekend too. Life is not fair. How, how did I get this kind of luck.

Man, why wont my mom turn down the news? Its so loud in hear. I reach and strech my tired arm while I turn my head and..and.. before I realized it I was watching a live news feed.Time stopped.


Wait, why is that plane so close to that building? Hold on, is that on fire? I choke out. I can barely speak, so I slap the coffee table. Slamming the remote down. Skin on wood, panic. My mom comes in and drops the phone. It is pure silence in my living room as we watch that second plane cascade into the secondbuilding. Complete confusion.


I can barely explain the emotion, and panic that crossed my moms face as she started to comprehend what was going on.I was 14, I didn't even know what the world trade center was.In the worlds slowest second she turned her head and said, "oh, ohh. That's New York. There are people.. people in there"


Noting moved. For so long. Slowly, it made sense to me. That was anaccidentor on purpose. I just witnessed in real time one of our countries largesttragedies. While my mind quickly raced through thoughts "how can people get out of there", "-wait, how many people are in there" Hold on.. "is that someone jumping?"

Robert Peraza kneels by his son's name at the National September 11 Memorial & Museum on Sept. 11


That day I received the largest dose of perspective. I will never forget that morning. That morning god handed me a massive attitude adjustment. I will never understand the choas of being in those buildings. I will never understand what it is like to go to work on a normal day and never come home. I will never understand grieving someone with an empty casket.That day I will never forget.

item.title: Personal//Do It Yourself
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
So I've recently been getting this slew of really sweet emails from my past clients. You see, when a beautiful bride books with us we have a phone appointment. This can last any where from twenty minutes to an hour and a half. Really depends on how chatty we're feeling and how much coffee I've consumed. This process helps me to ensure I'm pairing our new lady with the best artist for her party. This is also a really awesome way for me to connect to our clients and to get to know them.


In the past few weeks I've been getting a few emails from our newly married mentioning how inspired they were bymy storyand how it pushed them to get out there on your own. I'm not really sure why I'm sharing this.I'm just so stinking excited for them.


You see, working for yourself and stepping out on the ledge of"Istillhavetopaymyrent/thisbetterwork"is really really scary. It takes guts, stamina,organizationand tons of self motivation. Even with all the blood sweat and tears, the frustrations and stress. At the end of the day it is completely worth it. Every day I get up and I do what I love. I work with people I like, I am passionate. It doesn't even feel like work when you enjoy it.


If you aren't passionate about what you are doing, you are doing the wrong thing.I wouldn't change a day in my life, I'm so happy that I jumped off that cliff. It worked. I gave it a try and even if it didn't work, at least then I would have know that I gave it a try.

If you are thinking about getting out there on your own, do it. Take the first step, do a little research. I had NO CLUE how to build a business. [I sometimes still don't! -don't tell anyone] Every day you just wake up and walk forward. If you want it, you work for it and it'll happen.


Get out there.
Xo,
Alison


Ps. Congrats: Evan[Sweets by E]Kristin [Eleven Pepper Studios] and Andrea [Event Planner] I am super proud of each of you ladies!!

item.title: Personal//National Boss' Day
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
It was a foggy Tuesday morning as I walked through the doors of La Madeline with my folder in hand. I stepped inside the door, readjusted my skirt and patted my hair. Too nervous to eat anything I ordered acappuccino. That's what mature women drink, right? I find a comfortable two top near the faux fire place and set up camp.

At this point I am beyond excited, I'm nervous-I want this to go well.Minutes later a very beautiful woman a few years older than I walks over, "Alison?" Startled, like I didn't expect her my eyes go wide "Gabriela?" after a few hugs and simple greetings we sit down with our coffee.



Before this conversation I prepped myself 'don't talk too much', ' don't sound too green', 'make sure you put only the better things out there', 'she's older, She's worldly, so make sure she doesn't think you are too immature'

You see, I was hiring my first artist. Up until this nerve racking coffee date it had been my sister, Katy one of her friends and I. We needed help. I knew we were headed for better things and I knew I should start bringing good solid people on board. The only catch?I had never been a boss before.


Like ever. I was always the lowly starbucks barista, the stylist in the 4th chair down and the register girl at the IKEA. What did I know about overseeing things, telling people what to do and handling problems? Nothing. That's right, no training. So I did what I have always done with this company.Smiled.Smile and walk right through it. Deal with it as they come.


I explained to Gabriela that we were a budding company. We talked about the philosophy of this business. We talked about how I wanted to provide clients with an amazing experience and how I wanted to create an uplifting supportive workenvironment. I handed her a simple black folder with our menu in it and smoothed the lapels of my blazer jacket during our very professional lunch and prayed she couldn't guess how young I was. I needed her. She was talented, professional, gutsy and had a really amazing attitude. I was nervous she would turn down what I was offering, that she wouldn't see my vision and she'd take her leather bound professional portfolio with her.


Much to my surprise she loved it.She loved everything. She joined our team and has been here since the beginning. Just a few weeks ago we had a good laugh about our first meeting about 2 years ago and sheexplainedthat she never doubted what I was doing for a second. She said she saw my vision, she saw what I stood for and wanted to be a part of it all. When I asked her if she could tell I was nervous and scared she would say no, she reassured me that I looked as professional as ever.


Thank you to my amazing team of artists. I am so thankful to have a team behind me that furthers my vision, stands for the same morals, supports each other and makes me feel like I've got it all together.Even when I don't.

In the words of the great Micheal Scott:

"WouldI rather be feared or loved? Easy, both. I want people to be afraid of how much they love me. "


Xo,
Alison

item.title: Alison Harper Style//Rules OF Engagement
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Listen up.

1. Ask permission
Ask my dad, no dad; ask mom. Ask someone, listen to their advice. This
shows me that you have considered my family and their thoughts. If you
are a good partner, you have nothing to fear. This is important to bridge the
gap from my childhood family to the family we will create together.

2. Make it a complete surprise
This moment will only happen once, I will retell it when I am 89. Its pretty
important. Make it acomplete surprise.

3. Get someone to catch it on camera
This moment will be pure emotion, -private. This is a pledge to your future
person. That person, youremergencycontact, your cell phone plan sharer,
the second parent to your kids -your person. Never again will you lay your
heart on the line for me so privately. Capture it, that moment the words
dance off of your lips, while time stands still. Capture that moment thatI
absorb everything and when I finally say yes. I want a photoof that kiss.
Not just the one at the altar, I want the raw emotional momentwhen we
agree to change our lives, just between us. Every time I look at those photos
I will remember this life altering moment.

4. Get down on one knee
This shows me that you are willing to give me this. This moment. Show me
that you are willing to get on your knee. Show me that you will take care of
me, that you can bevulnerable willing tocompromiseand care about my
response. If you don't dothis, it will pass through my mind years later. I'm
not sure why, its just one of those things.

5. Let my best friends help with the ring
This is the least important option on the list but if you want to do this
perfectly, ask for help. I will love whatever you choose. Really I will but my
best friends have seen my pinterest board, theyknow I wear white gold not
yellow gold and they can help get my ring size.You don't have to tell the
world but its nice to know my friends helped.


These amazing engagement photos of Jd and I were taken by the fabulousChristine Barker

Xo,
Alison

item.title: Personal//This Is The Year
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
This is the year of exposed legs. Not being ashamed to roll up to a networking event singing Carrie Underwood's "blown away" in my old Ford Taurus. Its the year of getting to know my clients, accepting that my hair is short and that I'll never be 5'8. The year of game nights, date nights and relaxing bubble bath nights. The year I start matching my underthings, like a real adult. The year I work hard, but relax harder. This is the year I realize and accept that I am not built for skinny jeans, halter tops or knee high boots. The year I learn to mind my own and be happy with what I have. The year I pray and blog more often. The year of regular pedicures, good books and scarves. I don't wear enough scarves. This is the year. This is my year.


Happy Birthday to me. ..xo

item.title: Alison Harper//Business
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Let me first start this post off humbly. I by no means have it all together. Really, I lock myself out of the house on a regular basis. That is theepitomeof not having it all together. With that being said, I've dealt with a lot of business growth over the last 2 and a half years. With the volume of clients, artists, learning experiences and challenges I've worked through; I might boldly state thatI am an expert in challenges.[ha-ha!]

I should clarify that although I have been in business for a smidge over 2 years I have had a strong and fast learning curve. We have completed over475 weddings to date; 256 this year alone and over 25 photo shoots this year. I currently have two branch managers and25 artists on my rooster. I am not telling you this to brag, pleasepleasedon't take it this way. I am telling you this to explain our growth and to help explain my qualifications. Please know that I don't believe any of this would be possible withoutthe most amazing, talented and loyal artists.

Our very first wedding. July of 2010. Natalie was an sweet client with a fabulous setof bridesmaids.

Recently I've been getting quite a few emails and voice mails from other artists. A few of them just wondering how I structure my business, how I deal with this situation or that situation. The most common request I receive is "Do you have any advice or tips?"

That's a really broad question and I never really know how to answer. First off, I am so unbelievably flattered that anyone would take their time out to even email me. When I hear these messages, I want to reach through the computer and hug them. It is so refreshing and sweet toreceivesuch messages. I wish I could tell them exactly what they need to know.The problem is,I don't know what they need to know. So, I've decided to start a series of posts that pertain to my business and lessons I've learned. I hope that by sharing these experiences, something from one of these posts will help at least one business owner to grow or even to know that they are not alone in their challenges.

Caitlin hard at work on Emilie's hair. Thank youMichelle Lindsay Photographyfor the image!


Since I've written so much in this first post [andembarrassinglyso] I've decided that today I will keep it simple.No matter what industry you are in, you will face challenges working for yourself.No one will understand yourstruggles or the stress that is applied to you. No one will loose sleep, staying up all night working but you. The anxiety from the moment you overbook, overspend or rely on someone who didn't come through. No one will understand that moment you lay your head on your desk and just cry.

At the exact same time, no one will revel in the joy of yoursuccesslike you will. No one will get the same giddy feeling when a client leaves you a stunning review. You alone are responsible for this. You alone will will feel that amazing feeling when a client recommends you to someone else, the moment you nail that hairstyle, photo or makeup application you were aiming for, the moment you have that extra $30 to buy your husband dinner. No one will get the same feeling you do on that day that bride looks at your work and cries those happy tears. Or that one Tuesday you want to sleep in and skype from your bed.You made that happen. You have built this business from nothing with your two hands.

There aredefinitestruggles in owning a business butunderstandthat as long as the good out ways the bad it is completely worth every minute. When it feels the hardest just keep walking. That's it. Here's to you, owning your business. Taking the reins into your own hands and one day being able to retire on youryacht. [That is a joke. I don't even like boats.]


Make sure you check back in, I'll hopefully be blogging about this topic a bit. The next business post I have scheduled is,




The keys to building and maintain an amazing team.

xo,
Alison

item.title: Personal//The Long & Short Of It
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Since we've launched our fab new site I've gotten quite a few sweet emails. If you've throughly looked through our site. [I'll forgive you this time] You might have noticed a few photos from my wedding onmy personal bio page. I've had a few ladies ask to see additional photos of my hair from my wedding. HOW FLATTERING?!

Seriously. I love you all for telling me how fabulous I looked on my wedding. Not weird at all. I did get asked to see photos so I started thinking, I should explain the power ofextensions. You see, I've been struggling with growing my hair out. Its been a forever battle. My hair was only this long when my wedding rolled around:

Please do not judge me, I hadn't done anything to it the morning of the wedding. At all. That and we were getting ready in a high school dressing room. [That's Jen doing my makeup!] As you can see though, my hair is like barely a bob.

 

This most unflattering photo shows Gabriela and my sister Caitlin clipping in my extensions from the back. Why, yes. I am writing a letter to my soon to be husband in the middle of all of this. Which goes to show that no matter how much you plan things get hectic.

I used the Jessica Simpson Clip inPieces. Please note though: They wouldn't curl! I should've purchased untreated human hair clip in pieces. They made it work but it would've worked better if I used my brain.

 

Once they were clipped in, Gabriela and Martha started styling. I know, I felt like a celebrity. I was seconds away from yelling for green m&m's. Please see below.
Move over Mariah Carey.

 

Hours into our reception
Here is the finished product after a few hours. My hair was literally just long enough in the back to clip up, everything you see is basically extensions. The awesome part about this? I didn't get a trial for my hair. Crazy, no? I just trusted the girls to know what they are doing. I said, "I want something classic, low, secure and soft"

I like what they did. If you are thinking aboutextensionpieceswe love using them. We don't charge anything to put yourpiecesin and style them. I think they can make all the difference in the world for your wedding day do. Hope this is helpful. Don't worry loves, I'll post wedding photos soon.

Xo,
Alison

item.title: Personal//Sunrise Coffee & PJ's
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
I woke up the morning of the wedding with the sun. I was so so excited. Somehow, the serious amount of wine I had drank the night before didn't effect me at all. I wanted to throw open the windows on this beautiful February morning and yell. Today, I will marry him. The man I was made to marry. My dress was in its bag, my glitter heels, veil and necklace were ready to go. I could have put the dress on at 6 am. But, it was a little too early for that. I knew it was too early, I was in a room with some of my family and I'd just have to force myself back to sleep.


I rolled over and my mom was wide awake too. I nudged her, "let's get coffee" We snuck out of our hotel room leaving my little brother and his friend on the pull out couch snoring. I didn't even glance in the mirror. We stepped on the elevator while the whole hotel was sleeping. I remember looking over at her and chuckling, her hair was a mess, she had on my little brothers flip flops and we hadn't even changed out of our pjs. Iprobablylooked worse. We strolled by the front desk and I'm sure they chuckled too.



My mom and I spent the next hour sipping coffee and talking. I can't honestly remember what we talked about. All I remember is that we talked about everything and anything. It was an amazing start to my wedding day. Pjs, coffee, bed head -just my mom and I.Growing up as one of five children you kind of get stuck in the shuffle. As a middle child you get grouped in a lot of the time. I've spent time alone with my mom before but never like this. We had fought, argued and cried with this wedding planning. Anything that I chose she wanted the opposite. Anything she suggested I hated. We didn't see eye to eye with this wedding at all. It was the most amazing, magical 6 months but also the most tedious and frustrating. Sitting in that little dinner across the table from my mom in all her bed-headed glory, I could tell she was happy and excited for me. All of that frustration and arguing was behind us. I've never felt as connect to my mom as I did during our coffee sun rise talk. Her calm confidence that this was the perfect step for me made me calm and confident. I knew that this was right. I just knew it.

item.title: Real Wedding//Tammy's Beach Wedding at Herrington On The Bay
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Just a few months ago we had the pleasure of meeting Tammy and all her lady loves.
We had a trial and a few months later we drove out to Herrington on the Bay to help make them all fabulous.
The girls have been to Harrington before, but I hadn't. This was my first experience.
They have the cutest little cottages right on the water.
I want to live there.
That's not weird, right?

Tammy was really sweet.
At her trial she had her sister, mom and all the little ones running around.
We tried a few different styles, tweaked things.
Until we finally found what we loved.


When we arrived the morning of her wedding, all her ladies were in their matching "bridesmaids" shirts,
lounging around munching on snacks. Talking about how they knew each other.
Super cool. super laid back.
Super fabulous.
I loved how much family was surrounding Tammy on her wedding day.
Her sister helped into her dress,
her mom dressed her step-daughter.
It was really touching.
You could just see how many people cared for her this day.


Side note:
Tammy's hair was a real challenge for me.She wanted a style that I had some difficulty with.
I left her trial feeling like a total train wreck.
We tried quite a few styles, all of which were nice but not quite there.
All that struggle helped me grow.
I went home, I practiced. I studied and I practiced some more.
Her hair turned out to be
one of my proudest achievements.


Please enjoy these photos of Tammy's Beach Inspired wedding.
It was an amazing beautiful day for the two of them.
We were so blessed to be a part of their morning!



Hair & Makeup:
Katy & Alison

Can we talk about how beautiful Tammy looks?
Please, seriously fab.
-Don't worry, I burned that shirt and cardigan.-
so bad.
Omg, please look at his smile!
So sweet. I love seeing photos of the groom looking at his bride.
He looks like a kid in a candy shop.
So sweet.
I'd like to thank our friends over at Sapphire Style for sending us these gorgeous snap shots from Tammy's day.

item.title: Personal//Getting Back
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
This weekend, I had the chance to participate in a women's summit. I know, fancy sounding. Basically it was a small group of extremely talented wedding professionals. We opened up about our business and what our strengths and weaknesses were. We set goals and offered feedback. We were asked to bring our concerns with us to the table. When I sat back and thought about what I was having trouble with, only one thing came ringing like a bell. -How to enjoy life outside of work.

You see, as a business owner work never stops. I'm checking my cell phone for emails at my family dinner. Not because I think I'm that important, but because I think "what will happen, if I don't get back to this email quick enough", "If I don't blog x number of days, we won't have readers" or "If I don't do this right now, they'll leave an unhappy review". The list goes on,as a business owner you live with a certain amount of fear.It makes it hard to relax and to focus on relaxing. Meaning not feeling guilty when I'm out getting my nails done instead of being strapped to my computer.

That was my biggest concern. I brought it to the table and these fabulous women offered intense insight, advice and future reading material. Since then, I've been reevaluating my work life balance and learning to enjoy my life and my business. I'm saving myself from a future burn out andreviving why I started this business. I never thought I'd struggle to enjoy the small things but I'm getting there. Thank you to all the ladies I met this weekend. You are brilliant and offered me such wonderful feedback.

Xo,
Alison

item.title: Personal//My Husband. The Dreamer.
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
When you talk with my husband you don't exactly walk away feeling warm and fuzzy, inspiredor in tune with passionate zeal. He's a quiet, centered and simple man. In fact you'll think he's not listening when he is. Don't be fooled though, he is a collection oftangible, touchable dreams. He is the driving force in our house of jumping towards dreams.

A little under two years ago, my husband looked at me, squinted his eyes, cocked his head and said"What do you have to lose?"

He paved the sidewalk for me to begin my journey intoentrepreneurship. If I hadn't received a few uncomfortable loving shoves from him I wouldn't be standing here. His encouragement has lead me to places I had never imagined. I have worked hard and tirelessly to get here, but I can't take all the credit. He hascajoledme, pushed me and even helped carry me when I needed it here.

It is his turn now to be supported and tested. My husband has had this crazy dream for a while. I know it sounds insane but he has wanted to play Golf on a serious level since I've known him. Each day he walks between 18 and 36 holes with his clubs on his back, practicing the same chipping shot over and over and over again. I am in awe of him at times. I can't believe that passion for something could be so intense. It's his turn to start walking a path and I'm standing behind him giving him sweet little shoves now.


He is a dreamer, this one.

item.title: Personal// Independent Genetics
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
I have tried very hard to keep my personal life separate from my business. I think its more professional. Unfortunately, I feel as though I need to explain myself. I haven't blogged in a while, I havent updated facebook, I havent returned voicemails and I've been horrible about answering emails this week.
Me & My cousin/office assistant Abby, Rachel & Kate [Who model regularly for us] and sister and stylist Caitlin.

You see, this is a family business. My sister and cousin work with me. My brother helps with odds and ends in the office. Even Gabriela and Martha are sisters. We work with families and our team is as close as one.My family is unlike any other family I have seen. I know I am a bit bias but please know that I am not saying this is a good thing or a bad thing, It is just a fact. We are large, I can go into a grocery store, cook out or bank and I'm either related to someone or someone knows someone I'm related too. Growing up, my mom and a few of her sisters all lived in the same condo complex. There was an open door policy so whenever we needed ketchup we would run down stairs. Whenever a high school crush upset me all of my aunts knew before I could reach my diary. We fight, just like everyone else. The difference? We make up immediately. We love passionately, We forgive quickly. We are tight night, we are as large as an army and I promise you we are very different than any other family you have met.

My cousins, aunt and brother. Doing the chicken dance.

My grandmother was born in 1924, a time that wasn't great for women. She stepped outside of tradition and married a man who didn't belong to the Catholic Church. In an era that marriage was a womans life goal, my grandmother had a wedding in a catholic church rectory room, with very few witnesses and wasn't allowed to wear white. She married a man who shortly after the wedding day was taken off to war.

Can you imagine? In a time when a woman's pivotal life goal was to marry, she had a small ceremony and wasnt even allowed to wear white. Women didn't work, didn't go to college. They married. They married well, they had an elaborate event, dressed up and invited everyone. My grandmother sacrificed these things to marry a man she loved. Which sounds simple to us now but Iunderstandat that time it wasn't easy. She loved him hard.

Jean, my grandmother, had 9 children. The amazing part, only one of them was a boy. Yes, that is right. My mother has 7 sisters. Jean was pregnant 7.5 years of her life. That is insane. You have to think of the 40's and 50's when she was raising her house full of daughters. Women were raised to be housewives, they didn't have opinions, they were to marry and raise children. Women were paid less, respected less and seen as weak. Some how in my grandmother's graceful way she raised 8 beautiful andindependentwomen. She taught them to require respect from your significant other, she taught them the value of education. In a time where women professionally married I believe more than half of her daughters went to college. If they wanted a family that was fine, but they had options and they needed to take care of themselves. The difficulty of doing this in a time when women were arm candy to their husbands entraps me.These are qualities that have been passed down through my mother to me.

 

Caitlin [my sister], my grandmother and I

Please allow me to interject here. My grandmother was not your typical grandmother. She wasnt soft, she wasnt cuddly or going to coddle you. We never made sugar cookies or played dress up. Im not even sure what children do with their grandparents. I am sure though, I didnt do it with her. She was thin, picky and had a room called the East Wing we were never and still never allowed to walk into. It was a room saved for when the pope orElviscame to visit. Despite all of that my grandmother was fiercely intelligent and opinionated. I can remember her waving her hands and talking loudly at me when I decided to drop out of college. Even more so I remember the look on her face when she patted my hand and told me that she had been bragging to her bridge friends about her granddaughters business. She wasnt soft and cuddly, but she loved us and she had a way about her that you didnt mind that she hated baking.

My grandparents also had a very balanced marriage. During the same era, men rarely respected women or their marriage vows. My grandfather saw my grandmother as an equal, they were in their marriage together, raising a family. Together. They were married 65 beautiful, frustrating, rewarding years. Unfortunately the last 10 years of that marriage my grandfather was diagnosed and suffered fromdementia. If you aren't familiar with the disease go watch the movie The Notebook. It keeps your body healthy but steals your memory and your mind. My grandmother took daily care of my grandfather; bathing him,dressing him and feeding him until he passed away. Their marriage is something to be respected. I know it wasn't easy for them, but they loved each other. Their journey was long and rough but they held hands while they walked through it.

 

My only grandparents, Rex and Jean.

My grandmother stayed in her house and lived alone after my grandfather passed. I saw her at least once a week. We talked books, had lunch. She stayed active. She played bridge, had the ladies over. She was still so independent. That is until about a year ago. She started to complain about a pain in her back and legs. We had no idea what it was. We took her to a physical therapist. After a month or so of intense pain and asking her tostretchdaily they did a blood test. The details are fuzzy for me, but we discovered she had bone cancer. Think about this. We had an 87 year old woman stretching and cancer was taking over her body. How could we have not seen this? It turned out she had a cancerous tumor on her spinal cord, it broke a few bones.

Trips through chemo, back to the hospital because her vitals were low, arguments over medication, which doctor to see, should she be in the hospital? Second sets of chemo, cement in her back and more chemo. It has been a rough year. About a week ago, they brought hospice in. My grandmother's calcium levels were too high and there was no fighting it. They sent her home to rest and to die in the comfort of her own home. It was sad, disturbing and yet somehow beautiful the way my family and I stepped it during this bridge in my grandmothers life.We cared for her just as she had cared for her children when they came into this world.

My grandmother passed away this week. This strong, independent woman is finally liberated from a body that failed her. It was a heart wrench thing to watch, but she was well cared for and loved through it. She is now able to rest. No matter your faith, I trust that she is finally enjoying time with her husband and isnt feeling any pain. My family and I have been planning her services and they will be going on this weekend. I am telling you all of this because I want to explain my absence and I needed to share how intensely impactful my grandmother was on so many peoples lives.

I wanted to thank all of you for being so understanding and patient as I get through this with my family. Thank you all for your patience, I will be back in the saddle and cleaning up this mess of a desk and email inbox on Sunday.

Xo,

Alison

My amazing grandparents

item.title: Personal// 1 shade of gray, another shade of change.
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
My husband is many things. He's an amazing provider, a great golfer and very, very funny. He can handle almost anything I throw at him. Well he doesn't handle change well.

You see, I come from a massive family. I was raised in complete chaos. On any given night, we could have dinner at home, down stairs at my aunts house, across our condo complex parking lot at 3 other aunts homes. That's just a simple example. I don't come from a home of regular structure. We could do our homework whenever, so long as it was finished when we got to class. My sister and I had our own bathroom and I one time kept a pet turtle in our shower for two weeks before my mom noticed. I was a cheerleader, played violin, volunteered, played softball and was in choir at one point. When you have a single mother with five children you learn to live in the chaos. I was raised by avillage.


 Thank you toChristine Barker Photographyfor these beautiful images!
My husband on the other hand was raised in a beautifully structured home. I have to give his mother credit for raising such an amazing man. I wasn't there, but I've been told about his childhood. They had dinner at dinner time, they did their homework and they played outside. They had baths before dinner and everything in their home had a place. My husband played baseball and golf. He had 4 siblings, who each had their own room and their own chores. He was raised by two very caring parents, in a home most of us hope to build for our families.
Thank you toChristine Barker Photographyfor these beautiful images!
The clash comes in when we moved in together. We had our share of challenges, I hate dishes,vacuumingand laundry. He hates not having clean cloths. [See what I mean?] We eventually found a balance. We have a great working relationship, he does some, I do some. It works perfect. Until, I wanted to decorate.

We have been living in our condo for a little over a year. We're finally settled, comfortable and things have their place. That's when I started getting that itch. The itch that makes me want to pick up our whole home, flip it over and shake it. Knowing my husband, I decided to start small. We have a little entryway with a few stairs. The walls are white and getnickedup from carrying things into our home through that narrow passageway. I woke up yesterday and decided that wall needed to be grey.

Yesterday, [excitedly] I rolled over "Hey, good morning. I'm going to paint that wall by our door grey." No questions, no room forargument.

How did he respond? He rolled out of bed, got dressed and went golfing. Hedidn'tsay a word. Taking that as acceptance, I danced around lowes with color samples. Torn between "soft heather grey" and "satin silver fox," you would have thought I was repainting theSistineChapel. I ran home, taped everything up and slathered "London Fog" all over the walls. It was beautiful, and I did a pretty bang up job.

My husband called me 3 times during my painting extravaganza. He wouldn't come home until I was done. I figured, I should make this a smooth transition for my husband. Otherwise he would die when I ask to redecorate the living room. I cleaned up, washed the brushes and put everything away. When he finally came in, he looked at the wall, looked at me and grunted. That was it. A simple grunt.

That may not seem like much, but I know that grunt. His shoulders move just a little bit, his face tightens. That is his "It-looks-okay-Ipreferred-the-white-wall-but--its-not-worth-the-fight-I'll-let-her-have-it" look. I couldn't be happier. We are starting to learn to deal with each others challenges. By giving him the space to think things through and putting everything back to order before he gets home, he is comfortable. By doing those things, he has learned to allow me to do my thing. Unencumbered.

The two of us, so different, are learning a balance. This balance will get us through the next 70 years. He and I are so, so different. I am learning how to push him into change gently and he is learning to adjust to my chaos. It is beautiful. It is balanced.

I have one sparkling grey wall to showcase our beautiful, balance.

Xo,
Alison

Thank you toChristine Barker Photographyfor these beautiful images!

item.title: Ask The Artist/Which mascara should I buy?
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
I get asked a lot of questions. It seems as though every woman has questions about hair and makeup. Since I've been getting so many, I figured -why not go to the true professionals. Ask my artists. So, please enjoy this new segment! xo

------
Dear Alison,
I am not a huge makeup wearer but I always have on mascara. The only problem is that there are so many different kinds, I either end up with a mascara that's too clumpy or the brush is terrible. I finally reached my breaking point, after using cheap mascara for a while, I splurged and I purchased a really expensive mascara. It ended up being just as bad. Do you have any suggestions on which mascara to get?
Sincerely,
Lackluster Lashes

Jen Lee

My go to mascara is "Lights, Camera, Lashes" by Tarte because it's one of the only waterproof and natural based mascaras that isn't bad but it also does not irritate my eyes. If you are looking for a drug store alternative I would suggest "Mega Plush Volume" by Maybeline because it also does not irritate eyes and it also does not flake off.

Sierra

My favorite to use is Chanel "Le Volume de Chanel" in both black and violet colors. It has an amazing brush that grabs the lash at the base and really gives a plush, full effect to the lashes.

Libby

I love Max Factor's masterpiece max- but seeing as you can't get it in the US any more, I also love Lancme's hypnose doll lashes. It separates, isn't clumpy, smells like rose water (like diorshow), and has a tapered brush to help you get into the corners easily!
Tiffany
I second the Lancme hypnose but in waterproof because it doesn't clump up, builds up volume and holds a curl. For a drugstore alternative I would suggest cover girl lash blast, also waterproof. Mainly because any lashes that are stick straight, the waxy waterproof formula helps hold the curl.

Abby

I prefer NARS larger than life mascara. It contains vitamin E and oils that help strengthen lashes and it offers a beautiful finished and glossy look.

item.title: Ask The Artist// Dealing with fine and thin hair
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Dear Alison,
I saw this feature last week and I had to email you. I've always struggled with having thin hair. I've tried short hair cuts and different products but my hair either falls flat after a few hours or the products are too heavy and my hair looks just sad. Do you or your artists have any suggestions for what I could do?
Sincerely,
Furiously flat
Caitlin
Dry shampoo! It's something I recommend for all of my clients. Especially those who have fine or thin hair for two reasons. One, dry shampoo will control oil long into the work day. Two, it also allows you to get a second day out of your style. I recommend it for day to day hair but I also use it when I'm working on an updo.
Kaitlyn
I second dry shampoo, my favorite is bed head "Dirty Secret" another great product is bed head's "sugar dust." You apply it at your roots and it adds a lot of volume and texture to your hair.

Another suggestion is getting a highlights. Lightening some of your hair will add texture to fine hair.

When I blow my hair out I pin each section once I'm done into a curl. Then spray it, let it set, then flip my head over and shake it out. Once it is loose I spray with a finishing spray. I have fine hair so using a strong hold never works well with me, unless its up.

item.title: Alison Harper Style// Veils
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Veils have a rich history, dating back to biblical times and having different meanings and requirements for different cultures. It symbolizes modesty, protection and religious affiliation. That and they are gorgeous. No matter the reasoning behind your choice, we want to help you to find the right style.

Picking a dress has its own set of challenges. Finding the right fabric, cut and style for your body can pose some difficulty. When I found my perfect dress, I had an even more difficult time finding the right hair accessory. In my experience, I've noticed that most brides don't realize there is such variety with veils, nor do they know the correct vocabulary. To help you in your hair accessory search, we've put together this quick guide to different veil types. Here's a quick guide and a few examples.

 

Photo Credit: Wedding Fantasies

 


------

Cathedral Veil

This is the most dramatic veil, spanning over 3 and a half yards. This veil, usually worn with a dress that has a train will require someone to help lay it out before the big walk. This veil can be worn alone or with the blushed added [see below] Here is an example of the Cathedral Veil worn by our beautiful Alison Harper bride,Kelly.
Photo Credit:Deb Lindsey Photography

Lace Cap

This style, worn recently by Kate Moss. (pictured below) is sometimes referred to as the Juliet Cap. The name was chosen from depictions of Shakespeare's Juliet was pictured wearing a similar lace cap. This veil was originally produced in the 16th century and became popular again in the 1920's and 1970's. This veil can be varying lengths and is fitted around the crown of the head.
Photo Credit: Pintrest

Chapel Veil

Slightly shorter than the Cathedral Veil, the Chapel Veil just reaches the floor. It can be worn with or without a blusher and is a perfect accent to a small train. With a veil like this you have to choose your hairstyle carefully, just like the cathedral veil it can be rather heavy. An example is our beautifulAshleypictured below.
Photo Credit:Lauryn Galloway Photography

Pill Box Veil

The pillbox hat goes as far back as ancient Rome. Made popular by the late Jackie Kennedy. This type of veil comes in quite a variety. The veil sits atop a small hat that is secured to the top of the head. Sometimes referred to as a fascinator this veil is quite popular across the pond.

Photo Credit: Green Wedding Shoes


Finger Tip Length Veil

The finger tip length veil reaches a bit longer than the elbow length grazing mid thigh. One of the most popular veil lengths, it can be beaded, laced or left simply. It can be worn with a blusher or without. The finger tip length is the most versatile as it can be worn underneath the hair style or just on top without weighing the hair down. The soft veil as pictured on Alison Harper & Company brideKelly.
Photo Credit:Dani Leigh Photography

Blusher

This veil piece is a nice additive to a few different veils. A blush is the piece of veil that comes across the face and covers down to the bride's bouquet. It can be added to the cathedral, chapel, finger tip, elbow, ballerina and sweep veils. It can be sewn onto these veils or on a separate comb. Please note this beautiful blusher worn by our brideLiz.
Photo Credit:Wendy Hickok Photography

Elbow Length Veil

Another quite popular length of veil is the elbow length veil, which reaches to the elbow. Perfect for a light, airy accessory and doesn't overwhelm a tiny bride. It can also be worn with a blusher or as a simple single tier. As seen below a single tier elbow length blusher on our brideNatalie.
Photo Credit:Michelle Lindsay

Mantilla Veil

One of the most traditional style veils, the Mantilla, is fashioned after the lace scarfing that catholic women wore during holy days. It comes in a variety of colors, although most popular is white. It is usually lace edged and sits on top of the hair in the crown area as pictured below. Although they vary in length, most commonly they reach about ankle length in the back.
Photo Credit:Style Me Pretty

Sweep/ Ballerina Veil

Another popular veil length is the sweep length, also known as the ballerina length. This veil reaches between finger tip and chapel hitting about mid calf length. It is perfect for a taller bride or someone who doesn't want a veil that sits on the ground. It can be worn with a blusher as seen on our bride Alison below.
Photo Credit:Meredith Hanafi

Flyaway Veil

This veil is perfect for a bride wearing a dress with an intricately decorated back. This veil is just above shoulder length and is usually worn in one tier. Its light weight material makes for it to be easily worn in front or back of a hair style.
Photo Credit:Posh Veils

Bouffant Veil

This veil, the bouffant is not for the shy. Its layered and full texture has recently made a major comeback on the wedding runways. It is usually worn short and its layers are pinned together to create body and to stay out of the face. It is stylish, chic and.. well, brave.
Photo Credit:Style Me Pretty

Bird Cage Veil

Birdcage veils are generally short, fishnet style. Although most brides choose to wear them over their face, they can also be folded and worn over the back of the hairstyle. Most bird cage veils come with one to two small combs to help tuck it into the hair style. A secret hairstylist tip, you can spray the veil with a little corn starch spray, or hair spray if you're in a bind to get it into a specific shape. The birdcage veil worn across our brideMeghannlooks stunning.
Photo Credit:L. Hewitt Photography

 

 


Side Veil

Another brave veil choice is the side veil. It is usually work with a headband or small cap and a tie of tulle worn off to the side. Its bohemian style is light weight and is usually seen with intricate lace or beading. A striking veil choice for a bride with a simple dress.
Photo Credit:Style Me Pretty

item.title: Personal// Guerrilla Handbook
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
A few years ago, a close friend was getting married. During her bridesmaids brunch, she handed out books to each of her ladies. "I picked ones that I thought suited each of you, and since most of you hadn't been in a wedding before, I thought they were perfect!" I watched her dashing older sister open a leather bound, classic white book; I watched another girl open a beautiful hard cover, grey book with a gold bookmark. I tore my wrapping paper off to find this. This pale yellow, paperback monstrosity. The overview reads: : In weddings as in war, it always helps to be well prepared." I flipped quickly through to see a chapter titled:
"The Tour of Duty Begins: Getting the bride what the bride wants"
Instantly offended, I shut the book. I gave a brief smile and threw it in the trash when I got home. I was put off, is this the kind of "friend" she thinks I am?I'm the friend who would get down and dirty for the bride, making sure she had the perfect day.I'm the one that would help wrangle her drunk uncle from making a scene, I'm the one who would send the florist back to the shop to "Get the RED roses she requested!"

I wanted to be the friend who plans the classy bridal shower. The friend who helps organize the seating arrangements, the one she consults about etiquette. Not the low rung bridesmaid who would yell at the caterer. I was too embarrassed.

 

Years later, I still think of that book. My embarrassment and how people view me. This past weekend, I was with my little sister, dress shopping for her own wedding. We arrived bright and early on a Saturday morning, we'd made an appointment. She'd chosen dresses, we were ready. She didn't have a large party, just my little brother and I. We were going to make this exciting! Then they stuck us in the corner. Literally. I watched my little sisters face as they took the larger bridal parties into the big dressing rooms. You know, the ones with the little stage, special lighting. The ones with the seats for the bridesmaids and moms to sit in awe. I watched her face as we were put down the hallway into a cloistered dressing room. No seats for us to sit in, no mini stage. At first, I let that slide, maybe they were overbooked? Maybe they did this so we would have some privacy.

As I glanced around, I listen to the clothier ignore my sisters requests. She had looked across the room and seen another bride in a beautiful, chiffon dress and requested to try a dress on with that style. Behind that bride, an empty, stage fronted, bridal dressing room.

 

When the woman returned to the room, without the dress; my blood started to boil. We were here, just like those other parties. My sister deserved to have a beautiful experience, bells and whistles. When she closed the dressing room door, I saw that look. The look my little sister gives me when she's feeling defeated. A "why did we even bother look" Something in me snapped. I snatched the little sign off the door, my little brother yanked the dresses and we moved ourselves to that empty dressing room with a stage. While my sister was changing in her original room, I went up front and told the staff our clothier was rude and we wanted someone else. My brother and I went into the back of the store and grabbed the dress she wanted to try on. She was going to have this experience and it was going to be beautiful.
I realized this weekend that my friend had been right. I am that bridesmaid that would send the florist packing, that would fight for the clean hotel room, the one that would make sure that everyone bought the same shoes. I would fight for the bride to have a beautiful experience. As offended as I once was, I am not ashamed of that book anymore. I am that girl for the people I care about. Everyone should have someone who fights for them this way. For my sisters sake, I'm glad I can stand up for her and fight for her bells and whistles.
xo

Before the holidays really begin for me, I wanted to take a very heartfelt second to say thank you to a few very important people. My artists.

Truly, I would not be able to work on this dream if it were not for this group of talented women rowing in the boat beside me. I know that I get a lot of credit for things but I can honestly tell you that if it were not for this group of hard working, dedicated women you wouldn't know my name.

Each of these women have driven through snowstorms, purchased products over new shoes, stayed and worked with a client through a 5 hour trial or two. They have explained to their husbands and wives why they have to go to work at 3am and still love their job. They have dealt with mother-in-laws from you-know-where and they still smile about how they are helping people to love themselves.

I am proud to work along side these women, to have them on my team. Each and everyone of them carries a talent all their own. Thank you, to each of you for having my back this season. Let's have a beautiful 2014.

item.title: Ask the Artist// How to deal with oily skin
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Dear Alison,

I would love your help. My skin is always oily and I can't get my makeup to stay put. I feel like I've tried so many types of "oil-fighting" or "oil-free" products with no avail. Am I missing something? Do your artists have any suggestions on how to fight the oil and how to make my makeup stay longer?
Sincerely,
Not So Fresh Faced

 

Don't worry dear, NSFF my girls are ready to tackle your problem.I know the responses are lengthy, but my artists have a lot to discusson this topic. Here is to fresh, fabulous skin!

 

 

 

Sierra

I've broken my answer down into segments, as oily skin needs to be handled in a variety of ways!


Skincare: Oily skin still needs hydration! The reason your skin is oily is because it's overcompensating so that it doesn't get/feel dry! You need good oils in products! You want a cleanser for GENTLE skin instead of OILY skin. The cleansers for oily skin actually strip the skin of good oils and make the skin overcompensate. (Basically it makes you oilier) Make sure the moisturizer you're using is non-comedogenic (doesn't clog the pores) and includes light hydrating oils like coconut, lemon, lemongrass, and almond oils. All lightweight and easy for the skin to absorb. If you feel it's too much, try using it at night while you sleep so your skin can take in all the goodness!

Foundation: Anything with an SPF is going to make you look shinier! So, if you're not in the sun too much, you may want to opt for a foundation with out SPF.

Powder: Only put powder in the T-Zone, a little shine on the cheekbones actually looks youthful and gives a lift and highlight to the skin

Setting:A few of my favorite products include, Urban Decay's "All Nighter Makeup Setting Spray" or "Deslick, Oil Controlling Makeup Spray" Both are amazing! They help to set the makeup which helps to cut down on shine. I actually prefer these products to powder.

 

 

Tiera

After doing I bit of digging and testing out on myself, I've actually found that if you do a 10 min mask of milk of magnesia on your face, it keeps the oil from beading up in your makeup.

 

 

Kelsea

I second everything Sierra said! This is my exact skin type, and for most of my life I thought I had an oily skin type. But, in reality if have very dry skin and my skin is constantly trying to hydrate itself, in effect clogging my pores and causing blackheads! Taking care of your skin according to what it needs will allow a nice foundation set with primer and setting spray to act in a way they were designed to act. First, clean out your pores! Cleanse your skin with a creamy cleanser (has a similar consistency to lotion) for hydration and to remove clogged oil in the pores.


Secondly, Hydrate with a moisturizer. I love vitamin C based moisturizer because they rebuild collagen in skin cells, providing strength for long lasting healthy skin. I personally use the vital C line for my cleanser and moisturizer and have great results from their product line.

 

 

JenLee

Always have a good skin care regimen, no matter the skin type! Oily skin trends to lack hydration thus secreting out more sebum (oil) and while a moisturizer seems not necessary for oilier skins it's actually very beneficial. After cleansing the skin your body sends messages out that the skin is dry and to produce more oil. When moisturized properly you will help to counter act these signals. There are lots of great oil free moisturizers out there to choose from, but just because a product says it's oil free it does not mean it truly is. The FDA approves labels to be oil free if the product has less than a drop of oil in it. Just make sure the type of oil it contains is beneficial for oilier skin types such as jojoba oil, coconut oil, etc.

Including items such as a toner and serum is even more helpful for oily skin types. When you layer hydrating products you end up needing less moisturizer. Serums penetrate deeper into the skin and moisturizers just lay on top of the skin.Sometimes people just have a build up dead skin on the superficial layer which prevents all the wonderful skin care products from doing their jobs because all the dead skin build up is blocking all the good ingredients from the newer skin cells underneath. Exfoliating 1 to 2 times a week is key and also helps to prevent signs of aging. Lastly, using a good SPF is always a good idea for any skin type. Cancer is not biast and the UV rays from the sun are very damaging. They cause up to 80% of the signs of aging in a single life time.

As for makeup, using a good mattifyer under and or top of your foundation helps to control oil along with setting powders. A good setting spray also helps with the longevity of a makeup application and helps to keep the makeup from sliding around. Also, if your foundation tends to oxidize (turn darker) due to your skin's natural sebum try using a foundation that is a shade or 2 lighter.

 

Brittany

I have terribly oily skin and I've noticed that when I use skin primer before applying my concealer and foundation that it helps keep your foundation on longer. Once I'm done applying my make-up, I apply a generous amount of translucent powder over myentire face, focusing on the more oily areas, and finish up with my setting spray. The combination reduces shine and seals the look. For extra oily skin; like mine; I carry my translucent powder with me and touch up during the day.

My Recommended products:
Primer: Oil-Free Primer by Sorme
Translucent Powder: Translucent Powder by Ben Nye
Setting spray: Urban Decay's Setting Spray

item.title: Personal// Glam Session
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
These photos had to happen. I was asked to speak in a wedding wire webinar back in September. They needed a head shot to go with my bio. With little thought, I dug through my computer looking for the nicest "head shot shaped photo." I sent it over and forgot about it. A few weeks later, I logged in to host the webinar. I opened the power point presentation and immediately wanted to die. The photo, it was orange. The photo I sent made me look like I had a terrible spray tan. There is no easy way to explain. It was a bad photo. In my narrowed, hurry to send a professional looking photo; I disregarded the fact that it was tinted. Next to the other 3 professionals featured, the photo looked even worse. While the other guests were speaking, I couldn't stop staring at it. I still wonder how many people tuning in thought I had a bad spray tan. How could I, the beauty professional have such a terrible photo? I am supposed to be representing this beautiful brand and these talented artists. Once I logged off, I emailed my favorite glam photographer, Anna.

 

This post has been floating on my list for a few weeks now. For a few -admittedly, ridiculous reasons; I have been holding off sharing. Mainly, it feels a little self absorbed. A girl friend messaged me asking to see the other photos and then called me out on not having shared them. I realized that holding off wasn't about me. By keeping them under wraps I am not sharing the hard work of the talented Anna D Bruce Photography. By holding off, I wasn't sharing the talented work of one of our makeup artists, Jesseca. It wasn't about me. It was about my beautiful sister Caitlin too. This session was me embracing our new look, grasping the bedazzled bull by the horns and getting a little flashy. So, please enjoy the power of great makeup and an amazing photographer.

 

Thank you to the talented

Anna D Bruce Photography

item.title: Personal// Simple Reminders
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_2380" align="aligncenter" width="406"] Credit: Female Entrepreneurial Association[/caption]

 

 

 

I must have fell asleep with it open, my facebook newsfeed. Each night as I lie down to try to fall asleep, my mind begins to run at maximum speed. Like Sarah Jessica Parker in "I don't know how she does it"; I stare at the ceiling and mentally I rattle off a to do list that never ends. Its devistating, wondering if you'll ever get to the top of that list. Wondering if you'll ever get a half a step ahead of where you are and wondering where your last 24 hours had gone. To help stop the noise, I play on my phone. I know, every single sleep study says that it hurts your sleep patterns. Its the only way to quiet the very talkative to do list in my brain. I must've fell asleep last night with my newsfeed open. When I awoke to my alarm this morning, I unlocked my screen to check the time.

 

Only to see this lovely quote starting at me.

 

Call it fate, call it a basic, universal life reminder. Call it simply random, but it is exactly what I needed. If I feel defeated, than I am defeated. Simple as that. If I feel as though I will never get ahead, then I wont. Thank you universe for this quick perspective, this little life reminder. I am sharing it with you today, as you start off your Monday. You can have whatever you set your mind too, even failure. Just remember that. Happy Monday,

xo.
